title: Stock price prediction using Arima forecasting and lstm based forecasting, compatitive analysis
description:
Stock market is characterized as dynamic, unpredictable and non-linear in nature. Predicting stock prices is a
challenging task as it depends on various factors including but not limited to political conditions, global economy,
company’s financial reports and performance etc. Thus, to maximize the profit and minimize the losses, techniques to
predict values of the stock in advance by analyzing the trend over the last few years, could prove to be highly useful
for making stock market movements [1] [2]. Traditionally, two main approaches have been proposed for predicting
the stock price of an organization. Technical analysis method uses historical price of stocks like closing and opening
price, volume traded, adjacent close values etc. of the stock for predicting the future price of the stock. The second type
of analysis is qualitative, which is performed on the basis of external factors like company profile, market situation,
political and economic factors, textual information in the form of financial new articles, social media and even blogs by
economic analyst [3]. Now a days, advanced intelligent techniques based on either technical or fundamental analysis
are used for predicting stock prices. Particularly, for stock market analysis, the data size is huge and also non-linear.
To deal with this variety of data efficient model is needed that can identify the hidden patterns and complex relations
in this large data set. Machine learning techniques in this area have proved to improve efficiencies by 60-86 percent
as compared to the past methods

title: Management accounting
description:
Weight: 15%
Mark Allocation: 80 marks
Executive summary – 20% (10 marks) Report- 80% (70 marks)
Due: Due at Class 12
Overview
Refer to the Assessments page to download the Group assignment.
Instructions on How to Write a Case
The case response is the student's answer to the case question. There is no one right or definitive answer to a case question. However, a student should not conclude that there are no wrong answers. Case responses differ because of differing identification of issues and analysis of relations among issues, differing determinations of what the root or underlying issues are, and differing development of recommendations to resolve the root issues and, in turn, the other issues. Although a variety of responses are valid at every stage, some, clearly, are incorrect. The case response format is not fixed; typically it depends on the case question. However, using a simple, standardized form will improve case responses and provide a context for unambiguous marking. It is recommended that students use the issue analyses-recommendations framework, deciding for themselves, according to the particular case, whether to use the three headings or to combine the first and second or the second and third. The three parts are described and analyzed below.
Issues
Problems or issues are those attributes, factors, and/or activities that are wrong with the organization.
Students should read a case question once or twice to gather its essence. While reading, it is helpful to identify the issues by circling or highlighting them or by taking notes. Then, the student reviews these identified issues, adding to them any issues revealed by related analysis of financial statements and other supplementary information supplied.
In order to "size up" the root issues, it is essential to have a clear understanding of the organization and its issues. This analysis can be accomplished in two steps. First, make a list of the issues. Arrange and assemble similar issues into groups. Explain the relationships among the groups or categories that emerge at this stage. The groupings should be governed by two criteria.
First, same or related issues should be grouped together; for example, all issues related to inaccurate financial information would go into one group. Second, associations among issues within a group should be specified; for example, inaccurate accounting information led to poor decisions on inventory orders.
Second, the relationship among the categories must be explained. This explanation should reveal the root issues. Once they are disclosed, the root issues should be linked in a logical sequence. This listing should show the dependent relationship between the other issues and their root issues. Care should be taken to account for any specific requests that arise because of the role assigned to the student. The request may specify the perspective the student takes in assessing the issues. Requests may also be understood as additional issues.

 The primary reason for grouping and ranking issues is to detect the underlying pattern of root issues. Sometimes, issues may also be the same as the root issues. In others, the detection may be more difficult. For example, consider a manufacturing firm with several problems: sales are not growing as expected; customers are returning products; customer satisfaction with the product quality is declining; and rework has increased. The root issue, lack of quality control, causes the other issues. Specifically, there was no quality control in the production process. The absence of quality control led to more rework and to the shipping of defective products, which the customers then returned or refused to buy again, and persuaded others not to buy.
It is identification of the root issues that enables the student to specify succinctly what is wrong with an organization. Proper identification requires close reading of the entire case, including appendices. Some information may have little or no bearing on the issues. As in the real-life situations that case analysis seeks to emulate, the student must sift carefully through all discernible aspects of a situation in order to determine what is relevant.
Analysis
Analysis and issue identification are highly related. Analysis requires a thorough assessment of why an issue arose or exists, how various issues relate to each other, and which issues lead to others and are, therefore, the most crucial to an under standing of the root issues. The analysis section includes required quantitative analysis, e.g., cost-volume-profit variance analysis. The analysis discloses how well essential organizational functions are working, e.g., planning, controlling, and management information systems. Analysis can also reveal, when necessary, the strengths and weaknesses of the organization. The analysis may vary in complexity. It can be as simple as listing the supporting issues, or as complex as finding the root or underlying issues.
Some case questions have a singular answer either because of the context or because of the "required". Other case questions lend themselves to a series of alternatives for solving issues. Alternatives should be individually meaningful and mutually exclusive. For example, for a business with serious profit problems, one alternative might be to reduce costs and focus on the core business. Another alternative might be to close the business and sell the assets and inventories. Each alternative must be explained and justified as an answer, and if appropriate, its advantages and disadvantages should be discussed.
Recommendations
The recommendations are a student's approach to remedying the root issues. If there are alternatives, the recommendations should be selected from the alternatives discussed in the analysis section. In resolving the root issues, the recommendations must also resolve most of the other issues. Recommendations should be action oriented, decisive and unambiguous; i.e., they should explicitly resolve the issues, assign responsibilities and set deadlines.
It may be suitable to include a conclusion that deals with implementation, especially with timing, and the assignment of responsibilities that arise out of the recommendations.
For example, with respect to the organization with profit problems, a student might recommend cost cutting and focus on the core business alternative. The student should follow the selection of this alternative by specifying how he or she would resolve the profit problems, and by suggesting an implementation plan. The implementation should detail which costs are to be cut, by whom, and with what consequences. It should detail which businesses are to be eliminated

 and which ones are to remain. If sufficient information is available, the recommendations should be quantified, showing the expected profit improvement.
In the report writing stage, it is often more time efficient and effective to identify, analyze, and make recommendations for each root issue individually. It is nevertheless essential to show the integration of the various issues within the case. Whatever the approach, it should be justified as the most appropriate for the case question.
Use of Turnitin
To uphold academic integrity, Turnitin will be used in this assessment. By submitting your work through Turnitin, Turnitin's software will compare your work against a repository of internet and library resources in addition to the work of your peers and other academics to generate a similarity report. This similarity report verifies that your work is your own and that any referenced material is appropriately cited.
Submission
Students should save their excel file as one PDF file for the instructor to mark. Save this PDF document according to the naming convention: GroupNameAssignment.pdf. Include the names of all group members on the first page of the PDF. Then, one member of the group needs to submit your assessment on behalf of all group members electronically to the Turnitin submission inbox at the bottom (Part 1).
Click the "Part 2" tab at the top of the Turnitin Assignment to submit your excel file to show the calculations.
All course work submitted will require students in the course to complete and submit the academic integrity checklist. Please download the academic integrity checklist on the Assessment page and have one group member upload it under "Academic Integrity Checklist" tab at the top.
NOTE: Assignments will be considered incomplete if they do not include the required academic integrity checklist.
It is your responsibility to verify if the submission was successful. Be sure to keep a backup copy of all your assignments in the event that they are lost in transition.

title: Assignment: Conflict Assessment (Russia-Ukraine War)
description:
Word Count: 1500 words 

Topic: Russia-Ukraine War

Assignment Instructions:
Select a conflict case study and conduct a conflict assessment. Using research, identify the primary conflict drivers, key sources of insecurity, key stakeholders and their interests, and the interventions that have occurred or are occurring to keep and/or build peace. Apply the concepts and literature discussed in Weeks 1-6 to discuss the relevance of the security-development nexus in the context of this case study. This is a critical summary and assessment of the dynamics underpinning a particular conflict case study. You should engage with the course material to help you understand your case and clearly articulate your assessment (which is also your argument) of the conflict. Your conflict assessment should include the following:

Introduction: Introduce the conflict case study you have selected, and summarize your assessment into a clear and concise argument (you can think of this like a thesis statement – it is a declarative articulation of the central argument being made in your conflict assessment) (e.g. ‘While whole-of-government approaches have been attempted in in this context, interventions have failed to address one of the primary conflict drivers, thereby excluding a key stakeholder for peacebuilding). Answer the “so what?” of your assessment (e.g. The ongoing conflict in this context has led to mass migration, disruption of livelihoods, and has exacerbated the economic challenges this region faces. Failure to address this important conflict driver and include this key stakeholder in resolution efforts, risks this conflict becoming intractable).

Conflict Drivers: Identify and briefly explain the causes of conflict and the primary grievances that have led to violence in this context. Who are the key players? What are they disputing? Are external actors involved? Etc.

Sources of Insecurity: How is the conflict impacting civilians? What are the primary results of the violence? (e.g. economic precarity, displacement, sexual and gender based violence, genocide, political marginalization, etc.)

Key Stakeholders and their Interests: In this section, detail who has interests in the conflict or who may be impacted by how the conflict plays out. This is not the warring parties (as these should be discussed in the Conflict Drivers section), but is rather about what other actors may impact or be impacted by how the conflict plays out in your case study context. These may include international actors, transnational forces, corporations, non-state groups, political parties,
etc.

Interventions: Overview the types of peace-related interventions that have taken place in your case study. Have those interventions been successful or faced serious challenges? Have those interventions employed efforts at policy coherence by combining or harmonizing security and development? Based on your assessment of the conflict dynamics, what is missing from the interventions that have been tried or are being tried?

title: Own choice write-up
description:
Take up a couple of texts (short story, movie, case study, newspaper reports, etc.) and discuss them within the light of one of the concepts/frameworks discussed in the course.

Frameworks - Gender and development, women and development, women in development

Example topics - menstruation, discrimination at workplace, child marriage etc.

Word limit: 1300 - 1500 words
Zero plagiarism tolerance. Any such instance will lead to a non-negotiable zero for the complete assignment.

Readings done in class can be used for motivation (sorted by latest done):

1) From THE WOMEN, GENDER AND DEVELOPMENT READER edited by Nalini Visvanathan, Lynn Duggan, Nan Wiegersma and Laurie Nisonoff. The book is readily available online.
Chapter 9 Gender as a social determinant of health: evidence, policies, and innovations Gita Sen and Piroska Ostlin
Chapter 19 Subordination and sexual control: a comparative view of the control of women Gita Sen
Chapter 32 Caring for people with HIV: state policies and their dependence on women’s unpaid work Anesu Makina

2) 
https://www.epw.in/node/154695/pdf
https://scroll.in/article/921679/this-election-season-indias-policymakers-would-do-well-to-read-premchands-stories-about-farmers
https://theprint.in/india/how-caste-marital-rules-house-work-prevent-rural-women-from-eating-nutritious-diet/300683/

For the ones interested in intersectionality: 
https://www.vox.com/the-highlight/2019/5/20/18542843/intersectionality-conservatism-law-race-gender-discrimination

3) Sarbani Guha Ghosal (2005). Major Trends Of Feminism In India. The Indian Journal of Political Science, 66.4, 793-812. https://www.jstor.org/stable/41856169

4) Feminisms
https://diglib.bis.uni-oldenburg.de/pub/unireden/ur97/kap1.pdf
https://muse.jhu.edu/article/28377/pdf

5) https://www.econstor.eu/bitstream/10419/148819/1/863101828.pdf

6) old mail (contains repeated) Introduction to Nalini Visvanathan, Lynn Duggan, Nan Wiegersma and Laurie Nisonoff's "The Women, Gender and Development Reader." [optional]

Introduction to  Janet Henshall Momsen's "Gender and Development."

Introduction to  Cecile Jackson and Ruth Pearson's "Feminist Visions of Development: Gender, Analysis and Policy."

Precisely explained: http://people.uncw.edu/ricej/theory/Varieties%20of%20Feminism.htm

Judith Lorber The Variety of Feminisms and their Contribution to Gender Equality. https://diglib.bis.uni-oldenburg.de/pub/unireden/ur97/kap1.pdf
or [one can read both as well]

title: Case study
description:
This professional case study writeup requires you to analyses a real-life MCM/digital situation where problems were identified, how they were solved (or not solved), and lessons learned. Whenever possible, you should use relevant MCM concepts/framework/theory to this practical real-life digital/mcm situation; for example, apply the ideas and knowledge discussed in the coursework to the practical situation at hand. In this case study, the overall outline comprises of eight (8) sections. They are: 
1. Contextual Background Information and Analysis (20%)
Issues and dimensions to include: 
•	Background information: Industry/Company (Products/services; Markets; Philosophy/Vision/Objectives, Cultural diversity etc.)
•	Unit of analysis (UOA): Company (Huawei/Apple), range of product (Mobile phone/laptop), one product item (Huawei P30/P40/MacBook Pro 13”/MacBook Pro 14”) or specific MCM project
•	Business/industry/market, cultural and social environment trends and dynamics 
•	Customers: B2B (Business-to-Business) and/or B2C (Business to Customer [End-User], Buying/consumption behaviour/ Cultural, ethical and social considerations
•	Marketing Communication trends and dynamics/traditional and contemporary platforms
•	Assessment of UOA Digital/MCM emerging problems and issues
2. UOA’s Digital/MCM evolution: 20%
(Additional notes – To examine the “when”, “how”, and “why” of the UOA’s Digital/MCM strategies and initiatives. To use an appropriate framework (from lecture notes, journal articles, etc), accompanied by charts/tables and graphs, etc. Data and numbers presented to document the company’s evolution of MCM’s strategies and initiatives) 
Issues and dimensions to include:
•	Evolution and/or transformation of UOA’s Digital Marketing/MCM objectives, strategies and initiatives
•	Key strategic, people and culture, organization, customer, technology and ecosystem thrusts
•	Types of communication strategies/tools/ platforms
•	Timelines (Schedule) and Deliverables (KPIs) of evolution
3. Digital Marketing/MCM’s CSF: (20%)
Issues and dimensions to include:
•	Identify at least 5 CSF relating to UOA’s Digital Marketing/MCM’s issues and challenges. Examples: Personalising and enhancing customer service to a culturally diverse market; implementing multiple MCM’s strategies; Evolving loyalty programs; converting analytics to customer value.
•	Implementing, Communicating, and Monitoring these CSFs against (a) company/product [UOA] missions, goals and objectives; (b) industry/competitor’s MCM? (Marketing, MCM and non-marketing factors)
4. Lessons learned/Challenges Addressed: (20%)
•	Digital strategy enacted, aligned with corporate & marketing strategic vision, transformation; etc.
•	People Digital skills, Talent development, CIO & CTO leadership, Organizational and cultural diversity management excellence, etc.
•	Customers: Value and satisfaction; participation; new products and services offered; solutions redesigned; seamless integration, etc.
•	Ecosystem (channel partners, producers, relationship and network management with partners, etc); 
•	Investments in Technology and Innovation: Digital processes, Customer data management, Application interfaces, Big Data and AI, etc.
5. Clarity of communication: referencing and paraphrasing (harvard style referencing) (5%)
6. Clarity of communication: Report structure, format and flow of logic (5%)

7. How did the UOA’s MCM/Digital marketing strategies targeted people of different cultural backgrounds, in terms of their differences in lifestyles, habits, preferences and needs?  [No more than 100 words: 5%]. Support your position.
 
8. What are the implications of targeting people of different cultural backgrounds on the UOA’s choice of (a) media consumption habits (i.e. smartphone, tablets, PCs), and (b) online advertising (e.g. Google, Facebook, Instagram advertising etc)? [No more than 100 words: 5%]Support your position.

Growth of startups after the economic disaster led by covid-19.

Contribution of startups in boosting Indian economy

Comparative study between US and Indian startup market post pandemic

The tech firms are now at the stake-holding position of the capitalist restructuring during Covid-19 and post-Covid era

H0: Growth of Tech firms has larger impact on Venture capital startups
 
 H1: Growth of Tech firms have less impacts on Venture capital startups

title: BLOOD CELL COUNT
description:
PROJECT OF MRUNAL..
The aim of this paper is to segment WBCs and RBCs in the peripheral blood cell images into distinguishing images.WBC and RBC segmentation plays a critical role in helping doctors early diagnose some sign of the diseases which affected blood cells.In this paper, U-Net - an innovative CNN architecture - are performed for the identification and segmentation of WBCs and RBCs in images. To solve the challenge, we manually label images to create standard annotation images. From the experiments on two datasets, we conclude that U-Net is highly appropriate for segmenting WBCs and RBCs in blood images.

title: PR Campaign Analysis
description:
For this assessment you write a 1000 word analyses, selecting a campaigns and in each case focusing on a PR text as your object of study in each case. The campaign could be for any entity – an individual, group, company, political party, charity/NGO, government, etc. The texts can be a press release, a press conference, a series of media articles that draw heavily on a press release, an event, interview, or even a series of tweets.
Use one or more of the existing critical/theoretical approaches to public relations and apply it/them to your object of study. It is important to provide a critical analysis of your objects of study, rather than simply describe them. You ought to explain how the object of study attempts to persuade or to set the agenda, using the techniques of public relations.

You must write your analysis drawing on relevant academic sources to offer depth to your argument.

title: Assignment- Reading Reflection
description:
Students will write one reading reflection over the course of the semester (800 words). Each reading reflection should engage critically with the required reading for the selected week; as well as one additional reading from the weekly list. This should not be a summary; students should develop their own argument from the readings that discusses the main arguments of the readings, the points found to be convincing, and those that are unconvincing, with reasons. Additional research is not required, but students should be very careful to stick to the topic and avoid unsubstantiated statements. The reflection will be submitted on Brightspace before the start of class, and presented in small groups each week. The schedule for reading reflections will be arranged in the first class. Official citations, bibliography and page numbers are not required unless you draw on work outside the assigned readings. You may not use extensive quotes in your reflections. You are expected however to acknowledge the author to demonstrate you are engaging with their work (i.e.“as Murphy argued, market power...”). Include 2-4 probing discussion questions to stimulate discussion in class.

APA bibliography

title: Homework Assignment
description:
This Homework is a follow-on to Homework 3 in which we will add an inheritance component to the Book portion of the application. This will require modifications to both the design and code components of the previous assignment. The details are provided below.

You should create a new class called LibraryItem that will be the base class for the inheritance tree. It should contain at least the following data elements

1. ID #
2. Cost
3.Status (In, out, lost)
4.Loan period(how long it can be checked out for-note this could be 0)

It will also need appropriate accessor and mutator functions. You may also add additional data elements if needed.

 

Then there will be three child classes of Library Item

Book should contain the other items that we previously in the Book class not included above, at least:

1. Title
2. Author
3.ISBN Number
4. Category (Biography, Fiction, SciFi, History, etc.)

Audio CD should contain at least:

1. Artist
2. Title
3.#Tracks
4. Release Date
5.Genre (Pop, Classic Rock, Classical, Christian, Jazz, New age, etc)

DVD should contain at least:

1. Title
2. Category (Action, SciFi, Drama, etc.)
3. Run time
4. Studio (Marvel, Pixar, Disney, etc.)
5. Release Date

Implement the child classes, including virtual functions. Update the collection class be a heterogeneous collection using virtual functions and run-time polymorphism.

description:
Business plan sequence.

Dear students,

Please follow the below sequence for the business plan in a single word document

Part 1.
Cover page  with Matriculation no , Student name and Module code and Module Name

Executive summary.

Table of content or Index.

Then the 12 pages .

Starting with introduction and end with conclusion.

1. Introduction (Basically introduce your business idea with the help of WH questions, and support them either with Vision, Mission, Goals & Objectives or with Aims and Objectives or with other parameters)


2. Product Description, Analysis & USP (You can describe your product, How your product is different from competition?, and why people will buy your product? Use your creativity and showcase product differentiation and try to gain competitive edge over competitors)


3. Target Market (Whom you are going to concentrate on, could you give some demographic information about potential clientele with adequate justification)


4. Location (Why you have chosen a particular location, could you justify nearby potential environment, with the help of statistical information? or could we critically review the location with adequate justification)

 

5. Marketing Plan (What will be your marketing strategy, modes of marketing, how you will motivate and attract customers)


6. Personnel management (What will be your responsibilities for the business, do you need staff, then how many and why, what you will pay them and why, how you will recruit them, what skills or key attributes you require )


7.Start-up capital (Could your list which expenses can occur to start-up business [suggestion look for an on-line format - it will help] and you could also specify what will be your capital investment , operational expenditure and bank loan requirement)


9. Overheads (Could you take major initial overheads and give a justification, on how, you have reached to a particular amount)


10. Margin (What is your pricing strategy, are you going to consider food cost / labor cost / overhead costs, if yes then why and how)

11.Conclusion..

Part 2

Annexure properly arranged. Photos of land, menu and furniture


Part 3 

Accounts and financial detail

References list

title: HEALTHCARE TRACKER WITH LIVE CHATBOT SYSTEM
description:
Today, the application of artificial intelligence (AI) in healthcare is growing. Here, automated chatbot systems powered by AI have the potential to affect people's behaviour via promoting education, promoting health, and other functions. To forecast intake, it is necessary to investigate the driving forces behind using health chatbots; nevertheless, very few research have examined their acceptance to date. This study aims to investigate participants' openness to interact with chatbots for health care powered by AI. India's expanding population, rising birth rate, and lowering death rates as a result of medical advancements have led to a decrease in the number of doctors available to serve the country's expanding population.

To deal with such cases there is a need for a smart chatbot and Intelligent that can give advice to doctors and sometimes even patients about what to do in such situations that ultimately lead to the saving lives of hundreds of people. A situation because sometimes doctors can make a mistake while looking for symptoms but a specially designed machine cannot make such a mistake. This AI-based medical discussion can make a decision based on the patient's request. In this case, it uses its own database and in some cases where something is not available in its database at the request of the user, it collects information from a search engine like Google and provides it to the user in Audio format as Google does.

title: dissertation project
description:
I wanted to ask you if you would be interested in helping me with my  dissertation project. (NO DEADLINE)

For a bit of background of the project: 

I built a UML diagram (class diagram) using a UML modelling tool called papyrus. The cool thing is papyrus can automatically convert the UML diagram into an XML file.

This is where I need your help:

I have a java package called JAST. JAST is a package used to analyze/process the XML file. 

JAST has things to help me process/analyze XML files such as DOM parsing and XPath query.
 
I will have to write a program in java that reads the XMI file that then uses the XPath search (found in JAST) to pluck out all of the elements/nodes of interest.

XPath search is like Query strings in SQL but instead for XML files.

Here is the website to the JAST package website: (please note we will only be interested in two sections of the JAST which is DOM-parsing and XPath query so only look at those parts): 
http://staffwww.dcs.shef.ac.uk/people/A.Simons/jast/domguide.html

title: Stata Economic Data Analysis
description:
For my project, I seek to test if there exists any relationship between health expenditure and the growth rate of an economy. The chosen country is Germany and the time period of this study is 1980 to 2021. The Independent variable is GDP per capita and the dependent variable is health expenditure per capita.  As it is a time series data, a Basic stationary test of ADF is employed. It is followed by a bound cointegration to find if there is a long-term relationship between the two variables. The results were not statically significant, hence ARDL model is employed. Tests of robustness and stability are too performed.

As it is an independent project and my first time using Stata, I am struggling with interpretation as well as doubting the models if they are the right way to approach my research question. I wanted to test the causality too but as the ARDL model was statistically insignificant and there was no long-run relationship too as proven by the cointegration, I had my doubts about whether to extend the analysis further.

title: Library management system
description:
Gathering, Scraping, Munging, and Cleaning Data

In this assignment, you will be populating your database with real-world data. This process is often called data munging or data wrangling. All of your database tables must be populated with real-world data. Any substitution of simulated data for real-world data must be pre-approved by me.

The process is as follows:

You must find sources of data. (This can be downloads, XML files, JSON, HTML pages, data repositories, etc.) (10 points)

You must download and reformat the data to fit your database schema. (This involves using web scrapers, web API’s, formatting scripts, parsing files, etc.) (10 points)

You must audit the quality and estimate the amount of data you’ll gather. This involves auditing (i.e. testing to evaluate quality/accuracy - a systematic and independent examination of data). You will need to audit the following:

Audit Validity/ Accuracy (10 points)

Audit Completeness (10 points)

Audit Consistency/Uniformity (10 points)

 

This site is very useful https://datavizcatalogue.com/

 

You must clean and insert the data into your database. (10 points)

Each team member must come up with 5 more use-cases that involve a join between at least two tables. (10 points)

You must test that you can retrieve your data by implementing all of the use-cases in that you created in all of the assignments so far. (10 points)

In addition, you must:

Respond to any feedback you received in assignment 2. (10 points)

A brief README document explaining all of the files, the tests and their results and code. (10 points)

Design Requirements

Your submission must include:

Sample data from every table.
SQL for all of your inserts and queries
Any code and scripts you used
A brief README document explaining all of the files, the tests and their results and code.
Scoring Rubric

(10 points) You must find sources of data.
(10 points) You must download and reformat the data to fit your database schema
(10 points) Audit validity/ accuracy
(10 points) Audit completeness
(10 points) Audit consistency/uniformity
(10 points) SQL to insert the data into your database. Scripts to clean your data.
(10 points) Each team member must come up with 5 more use cases that involve a join between at least two tables.
(10 points) You must test that you can retrieve your data by implementing all of the use cases in that you created in all of the assignments so far.
(10 points) Respond to any feedback you received in assignment 2.
(10 points) A brief README document explaining all of the files, the tests, and their results and code.

title: Assignment
description:
Are policy making and intervention design based on the security-development nexus beneficial to conflict response? Use research to collect evidence (case studies, reports, literature, assessments etc.) and construct an argument for if, when, under what conditions, etc. the security-development nexus makes conflict interventions more or less effective and/or sustainable.

Your paper should include an introduction; a clear and compelling thesis statement (argumentative, not just a statement of purpose); an evidence-based argument in support of your thesis that is well-structured; a conclusion that summarizes your argument and is forward looking (suggest avenues for further inquiry, suggest changes to organizational and institutional structures to support more effective interventions, suggest pathways for alternative intervention
approaches, etc.).

Please refer to the Academic Writing Conventions, Essay Writing, and Citation documents available on Brightspace under Content, sub-heading Academic Resources.

Word Count: 2500 (Without Bibliography)

title: Implement a program that computes and prints out the JPD value of any combination of events. If the executable is called bnet
description:
For the Bayesian network of Figure 1, implement a program that computes and prints out the JPD value of any combination of events. If the executable is called bnet, here is an example invocation of the program

To print out the probability P(Burglary=true and Earthquake=false and Alarm=false and MaryCalls=false and JohnCalls=true

bnet Bt Ef Af Mf Jt

The implementation should not contain hardcoded values for all combinations of arguments. Instead, your code should use the tables shown in Figure 1 and the appropriate formulas to evaluate the probability of the specified event. It is OK to hardcode values from the tables in Figure 1 in your code, but it is not OK to hardcode values for all possible command arguments. More specifically, for full credit, the code should include and use a Bayesian network class. The class should include a member function called compute probability(b, e, a, j, m), where each argument is a boolean, specifying if the corresponding event (burglary, earthquake, alarm, john-calls, mary-calls) is true or false. This function should return the joint probability of the five events.

title: Library management system
description:
Normalization

Database normalization is the process of organizing the attributes and tables of a relational database to minimize data redundancy.

Normalization involves refactoring a table into smaller (and less redundant) tables but without losing information; defining foreign keys in the old table referencing the primary keys of the new ones. The objective is to isolate data so that additions, deletions, and modifications of an attribute can be made in just one table and then propagated through the rest of the database using the defined foreign keys.

Edgar F. Codd, the inventor of the relational model (RM), introduced the concept of normalization and what we now know as the First normal form (1NF) in 1970. Codd went on to define the Second normal form (2NF) and Third normal form (3NF) in 1971.

Design Requirements

 

You will check whether your tables are in First normal form (1NF), Second normal form (2NF) and Third normal form (3NF).  If not, you’ll restructure your database so that all of the tables are in Third normal form; that is, you normalize the database.

 

Your submission must include:

A check that your tables are in First normal form (1NF)
A check that your tables are in Second normal form (2NF)
A check that your tables are in Third normal form (3NF)
The final SQL of a normalized database in Third normal form (3NF).
Views for all of your use-cases
 

First normal form (1NF)

Each table has a primary key: minimal set of attributes which can uniquely identify a record
The values in each column of a table are atomic (No multi-value attributes allowed).
There are no repeating groups: two columns do not store similar information in the same table.
 

 

Second normal form (2NF)

All requirements for 1st NF must be met.
No partial dependencies.
No calculated data
 

 

Third normal form (3NF)

All requirements for 2nd NF must be met.
Eliminate fields that do not directly depend on the primary key; that is no transitive dependencies.
 

Create Views Syntax

 

CREATE VIEW  Miley_Tweets AS

SELECT Tweets.tweetid, Tweets.text, Users.screen_name 

FROM Tweets

JOIN Users ON (Users.userid = Tweets.userid)

WHERE Users.screen_name=  ="MileyCyrus";

 

Scoring Rubric

(25 points) Check that your tables are in First normal form (1NF)
(25 points) Check that your tables are in Second normal form (2NF)
(25 points) Check that your tables are in Third normal form (3NF) and the final SQL
(25 points) Views for all of your use-cases

title: Launching New Ventures
description:
Individual Report
3, 000 words worth 75% of module mark.

Deadline: 3pm GMT, January 12th, 2023 online submission via Moodle link

There are two parts to the individual report:

Part 1: Essay (70%) evaluating theoretical frameworks and concepts explaining the process of launching new ventures.  Your report should demonstrate wide reading and comprehension of the theoretical frameworks introduced in the module. You are expected to draw on key concepts and frameworks to analyse the process of launching new ventures. Good reports will draw on theoretical concepts to show understanding of the challenges typically encountered when creating a new venture. This may include frameworks explaining the influence of uncertainty and related knowledge problems on new ventures; strategies for creating new firms, the founders’ role, and how entrepreneurs can overcome challenges such as resource dependency and liabilities of newness/scale.

Part 2: A Self-reflection (30%)  Written in the first person (I) this part of the report should demonstrate your personal understanding of the process of creating a new venture. You do not need to draw on theoretical frameworks in Part 2. Instead, you can draw on previous entrepreneurial experiences (e.g., founding your own firm, working for start-ups, entrepreneurial competitions (e.g., Ingenuity) internships, family business etc). It may also be helpful to draw on your experiences during this module. For example, what insights did you gain from designing a Business Model for a new venture? What might you do differently? Finally, you may project into the future to consider how you would approach the process of launching a new venture. Have you gained any insights from this module that you would use in the future if you were creating your own venture or joining a start-up?

Some key points to consider:

1)   The individual report requires two parts: Part 1 is a standard academic essay with references, introduction, discussion, and conclusion. Part 2 is a self-reflection written in the first person (I) and based on your personal understanding of the process of launching a new venture.

2)   A marking rubric for the individual report is provided on Moodle.  Summarising from the rubric, a good report must demonstrate the following:

Understanding of theoretical frameworks introduced during the module to explain the process of launching new ventures;
A clear explanation of what business models are and why they are relevant for launching new ventures;
Evidence of comprehension based on high quality and wide ranging referencing of literature included in the reading list;
Self-reflection showing personal understanding of the process of launching a new venture.
Well structured, rigorous and logical report.
Word count specified is to be strictly adhered to. A penalty will be applied if this is not adhered to.

Coursework Submission Requirements:

The maximum word count (3, 000) is set by the module convenor and must be adhered to. The penalty for exceeding this limit is a five mark deduction.

The actual word count of the assignment must be stated by the student on the first page (cover sheet) of the assignment.
The overall word count does include citations and quotations.
The overall word count does not include the references at the end of the report.
The word count does not include figures and tables.
Appendices may be included and are not included in the word count.
Students should prepare and submit their coursework assessments in the following format:

Font:                       Verdana 12 point
Spacing:                 1.5 spaced
Margins:                 Normal (2.5 cm)
Referencing:          Harvard citation style

description:
Your essay should follow these rules:

·       Examine the essay question.  Make sure you are answering all parts of the question, and not just describing the material presented. For example, for question 3, do not just describe the paradigm, but address empirical evidence. Read some original sources.

·       Structure – you must structure the material in a way that allows for a logical sequence of ideas. Each paragraph / statement should follow sensibly from its predecessor. The essay should 'flow'.

·       Elements: Your essay should have an introduction paragraph, a main body and a conclusion.  These sections should all be linked.
       Each paragraph should comprise a main theme that is illustrated and developed through a number of points (supported by evidence).

·       Knowledge and Understanding - recognise, recall and show understanding on a range of materials that accurately reflects the main theoretical perspectives. Evidence of wide reading is essential for higher grades.

·       Critical Evaluation - arguments should be supported by appropriate evidence and/or theory from the literature. All facts MUST be cited.  Evidence of independent thinking, insight and evaluation of the evidence.

MARKING RUBRIC
Detailed information about the marking rubric used for this first assignment can be seen in this document. We use a categorical marking scheme:

• Distinction – 72, 75, 80, 85, 90, 95
• Merit – 62, 65, 68
• Pass – 52, 55, 58

Projects present challenges to the Project Manager, not just in their planning and operation, but also 
in terms of effective leadership, management of all interested parties. There are key areas which 
need to be considered when evaluating the success of a project. These can involve various 
perspectives depending on experience, knowledge, cultural values, and self-interest. Managing to 
initiate a project and maintain progress and required quality to completion can be difficult for the 
Project Manager. 
 
For this assessment you are to choose a past project where it is no more than 6 years since project 
closure. You are to write a critical review of the literature in which you should consider the 
following areas. 
 
• Key issues in managing people in projects including leadership and teamwork, and how 
leadership can be used to improve team performance. 
 
• The factors that can impact on the quality of a project or engineering activity 
 
• The impact of leadership style and team performance on quality issues in your chosen 
project

title: Research Analysis (Autumn Semester). -- VARUN
description:
Aim and objectives of your research, which should be clearly stated. Please 
number the objectives (please see Session 2-Research Motivation).
o Explanation of your research topic motivation supported by factual data about the 
significance of that research (please see Session 2-Research Motivation). Any 
funding opportunity, statistics, roadmaps, governmental report, etc. can be used to 
support the research significance.
o Narrative of the literature review, which should be explained in detail (see Lecture 
4-Performing a Comprehensive Literature Review). What would be the steps 
(the pathway) that will be later taken to explain the related state-of-the-art to your 
own research topic. Note that this section is not a about conducting literature 
review, but to explain that how you will do this later on.
o The possible methods (modelling approaches), which should be first identified 
(please see Lecture 5-Choosing a Methodology). Then, in respect to your 
selected research plan, you should explain how your method is aligned with the 
proposed objectives. And, how you would be able to reach to the goal (aim).

title: Organisations and Systems Assignment
description:
The tools and techniques covered within the module organisations and systems are aimed at investigating, understanding and modelling of organisations and systems.

You are therefore required to critique each of the following tools and techniques (please note each tool and technique has an equal weighting) and critically discuss how each of the tools/techniques might be used in analysing the Volvo Self-Driving (Autonomous) Car Project. See below for further information.
Tools:
1.	SWOT Analysis
2.	PESTEL
3.	Porters Five Forces analysis
4.	Data Modelling
5.	Process Modelling
Techniques:
1.	Interviewing (as part of an investigatory study)
2.	Questionnaires (as part of an investigatory study)

Appendices
In addition, you are required to submit appendices which represent evidence of the practical application to the tools to the given case study, which you should also refer to in the main body of the appraisal. Please note that each appendix submitted must have been clearly developed by yourself.
(Please note appendices do not count towards the word count)

Part 2 (20%) – Organisational and Systems analysis – Tools/Techniques applied (600 words + - 10%)
 


Part 2 of the assignment is split into two parts (part 2a and part 2b) and can be based on (in) an automotive manufacturing organisation of your choice:

Part 2a. – Soft Systems - Rich Picture (10%)
Choose an automotive organisation / business and generate a ‘Rich Picture’ which portrays the customer/supplier/manufacturer relationship e.g. Innoson Motors. Your analysis should be drawn from the perspective (viewpoint) of the customer who is using the products or services and should consider points of potential conflict and inter connectivity between the different parties, customer / supplier /Manufacturer.
Please state any assumptions you make when producing the model.

Part 2b. – Workshop Planning (10%)
You have been asked to plan a 90 minute workshop involving staff from the organisation of your choice. This workshop aims to develop a better working relationship between the management and staff within the organisation, prior to the introduction of new working practices. You are therefore required to set out a plan and briefly discuss how you would run this workshop, from the opening introductions to facilitating the discussion and finally to how it would be concluded. This can be submitted bullet point form and a maximum of three pages long.

title: Agricare
description:
Write a research paper for Machine Learning and IOT combined project called AGRICARE.A Web application is created using Python-Flask Framework and frontend technologies of HTML,CSS,JS.

It has features such as 
1.Crop Prediction - Crop predicted using Logistic regression Machine learning algorithm using inputs of Nitrogen, Phosphorous, Potassium, pH, Rainfall ,Temperature.

2. Fertilizer Prediction - Fertilizer predicted using Logistic regression Machine learning algorithm using inputs of Nitrogen, Phosphorous, Potassium, Crop for which the fertilizer is required.

3.Disease Prediction - Photos of infected leaves should be uploaded and the disease is predicted using open cv in Machine Learning.

4.Agri-Hub - In this feature we have enlisted the Government centers in different regions of Maharashtra where the farmers can test the soil and get the readings for their soil.

5.Smart Irrigation System:-
To make the sustainable irrigation system and old monitoring system for getting better crops growth as well as best production, this IOT based Automatic irrigation system is proposed. In this system IOT and WSN are used to control and monitor the irrigation system. IOT is used to obtain stored data monitoring and real time monitoring of various contents of soil. WSN is used to make a fully wireless system to make a user-friendly system to cultivate and irrigate water properly to the eld.  Different kinds of sensors are used. This report presents a fully automated irrigation system which is controlled and monitored by using “Thing speak Cloud Server”. Temperature and the humidity content of the soil are frequently monitored.

A Web application is created using Python-Flask Framework and frontend technologies of HTML,CSS,JS.

title: Reflective statement
description:
Element 1 – Company Briefing Paper
You should choose one of the topics below as the subject of 2,000 words (maximum) fully-referenced Company Briefing Paper. Your chosen topic designates you as an “Expert” at the relevant Roundtable Experts & Novices workshop sessions (see Element 3 below).
Please note that a limited number of places will be available for each topic, therefore you should choose a secondary topic as a back-up. A topic sign-up list will be available on Canvas closer to the time.
· Brand placement
· Sponsorship
· Ethics in Marketing Communications
· Customer Journey Communications
  
· Interactive/Digital & mobile communications
The Company Briefing Paper must be written in the 3rd person and provide the Marketing Director of a fictitious company (see below for choice of companies) with the following:
§ Anup-to-date,criticalreviewoftheacademicliteratureinyourchosentopic area
drawing on an absolute minimum of two carefully selected academic journal
articles and on a range of at least ten diverse sources.
§ Integrateintoyourdiscussionatleasttwoexamplesofhowtheacademic
theory reviewed is used/ applied by brands/ companies in current practice. Here, you should draw on practitioner sources such as the trade press (e.g. Marketing Week), newspaper articles (e.g. The Guardian) and news sources (e.g. BBC), and blogs, articles and websites written by credible industry commentators and experts.
§ Recommendations for how the fictitious company should take the issues
raised in your briefing paper into account in their future marketing
communications.
In this way, your Company Briefing Paper will pull together the academic literature on a topic with examples drawn from marketing practice. Employers put a high value on candidates who can demonstrate skills in critical thinking, synthesising (bringing together) material from different sources, and analysing complex material.
You should choose any ONE of the fictitious companies shown below as the focal company for your Company Briefing Paper.
Company A: Get Fit Now is a new pay-as-you go gym, targeting consumers who have become disillusioned by high joining and membership fees of health clubs. As a newcomer they need to build awareness very quickly and ensure that potential customers understand their position in the market place.
Company B: Bio-gloss is a brand of shampoo and hair care products targeted at a young teenage female audience. The products are positioned as fun, stylish, “must-

have” items aimed at encouraging young girls (12-17 years old) to get into a regular hair care routine.
Company C: Nice Ice is a chain of ice cream cafes targeted at teenagers and their parents. Positioned as a trendy place to hang out with friends, the chain plans to open 25 outlets in large towns within a year.
Company D: Green-Phone is a new brand of smart phone positioned as sustainable. It is targeted at consumers who need to replace their phone whilst reducing their impact on the environment. The company’s marketing objective is to seize a 10% market share in the mobile phone market in year 1 by building awareness and trial rapidly.
Key elements of a Company Briefing Paper
Please note that this is an indicative list only of what should be included in your work, it is nota running order or list of contents: thus, the logic and flow of material is up to you to decide.
§ Introduction to the paper (what is the purpose of the paper and what it will cover?)
§ Criticalanalysisanddiscussionofacademictheoryinyourchosentopicarea. You should aim to focus your discussion on any issue that you consider to be of relevance/ importance/ interest – but – be careful to scope it in. Do not be tempted to cover too many issues. Remember, your aim is to offer a critical discussion, not to simply describe one article after another – thus, you should aim to go for depth rather than breadth. For example, is there an area of controversy or divided opinion in the subject area, e.g. where researchers have found different or conflicting results?
§ Examples–integratepractitionersourcestodemonstratehowtheissues raised in your review of the academic literature are used /applied in the case of at least two companies/ organisations/ brands in their marketing communications
§ Conclusions and recommendations: what conclusion do you draw from the review of the academic literature? Based on this, what recommendations would you make to the Marketing Director of your chosen fictitious company?
§ References: ALL sources used in the work must be shown in accurate Harvard style, including the in-text citations and the Reference list at the end of the work.
   
§ Appendices are optional and should be used only if there is a need to include any supporting information.
§ Presentation style – your paper must be presented to professional standards and demonstrate a coherent structure. It should include a title page, contents page, page numbers, and a clear system of appropriate headings and sub- headings.
Element 2 – Reflective statement on the research process
The Company Briefing Paper requires you to find, evaluate and use information drawn from a range of academic and practitioner sources. The ability to carry out information search and demonstrate reflective professional practice are important skills that employers are looking for.
For the reflective statement, therefore, you should write 200 words reflecting on your research process and the trustworthiness of the sources you have used. You should address:
§ How did you judge whether your sources were credible and reliable?
§ What did you learn from the research process in undertaking this assignment?
§ How might you take this learning forward into your professional life?
The reflective statement should be inserted in a separate section at the very end of your Company Briefing Paper, after the references and any appendices, and NOT as
a separate document.

For more read file attached below

title: Report
description:
Q1. You can choose any international company, who has faced any one of the country risks: political, economic, operational or competitive, in the last 12 months in one of the following regions: 1) South America, 2) Africa, 3) Central Asia, and 4) Middle East. Identify, analyse and manage the risk as if you were employed as a consultant by your chosen company. Any risk management technique which has already been adopted and used by the chosen company will NOT be accepted in your answer. (500 words)
 
Q2. You have been promoted to HR Director in the Swedish company which manufactures and sells the medical equipment (MRI scanner). Being very hi-tech, the equipment has until now been made in Sweden by the company’s skilled team. Your employer has just purchased a factory in Mexico for the manufacture of medical equipment that have been selling well in the USA. There is a budget for three expatriate managers to be sent to manage its operation in Mexico for four years. The CEO has asked you to recommend the job title for three expatriates with your justification for each job title and prepare a plan to help these expatriates’ early settlement in Mexico. (500 words)
 
Q3. Choose any international company who has outsourced one of its business functions to a local company in their international operation (For example:  DHL’s use of local Indian company for its inbound freight distribution in India) and critically discuss the benefits and drawbacks of its outsourcing arrangement with the local company. An outsourcing arrangement between the two companies should be post 2010. (500 words)

title: Marketing communications
description:
You will choose one Marketing Communication topic out of a list of five, topic in which you will become an ‘expert’ by researching a range of sources. You will write up an up-to-date, critical review of the academic literature in your chosen topic area, as well as some recommendations to a fictitious company (to be chosen from a list of four) on how this company should take the issues raised in your briefing paper into account in their 
future marketing communications.

The individual assignment comprises of three elements:

1.    A fully-referenced Company Briefing Paper (2,000 words maximum)

2.    A reflective statement on the research process (200 words maximum)

3.    Preparation for and contribution to five “Experts and Novices” roundtables, including a TAG (Thematic Analysis Grid). 

 The task

Element 1 – Company Briefing Paper

You should choose one of the topics below as the subject of 2,000 words (maximum) fully-referenced Company Briefing Paper.  Your chosen topic designates you as an “Expert” at the relevant Roundtable Experts & Novices workshop sessions (see Element 3 below).

Please note that a limited number of places will be available for each topic, therefore you should choose a secondary topic as a back-up. A topic sign-up list will be available on Canvas closer to the time.

·       Brand placement

·       Sponsorship

·       Ethics in Marketing Communications

·       Customer Journey Communications

·       Interactive/Digital & mobile communications

 

The Company Briefing Paper must be written in the 3rd person and provide the Marketing Director of a fictitious company (see below for choice of companies) with the following:

An up-to-date, critical review of the academic literature in your chosen topic area
drawing on an absolute minimum of two carefully selected academic journal 
articles and on a range of at least ten diverse sources.  
Integrate into your discussion at least two examples of how the academic theory reviewed is used/ applied by brands/ companies in current practice. Here, you should draw on practitioner sources such as the trade press (e.g. Marketing Week), newspaper articles (e.g. The Guardian) and news sources (e.g. BBC), and blogs, articles and websites written by credible industry commentators and experts. 
Recommendations for how the fictitious company should take the issues raised in your briefing paper into account in their future marketing communications.
In this way, your Company Briefing Paper will pull together the academic literature on a topic with examples drawn from marketing practice. Employers put a high value on candidates who can demonstrate skills in critical thinking, synthesising (bringing together) material from different sources, and analysing complex material.

 

You should choose any ONE of the fictitious companies shown below as the focal company for your Company Briefing Paper. 

Company A: Get Fit Now is a new pay-as-you go gym, targeting consumers who have become disillusioned by high joining and membership fees of health clubs. As a newcomer they need to build awareness very quickly and ensure that potential customers understand their position in the market place.  

Company B: Bio-gloss is a brand of shampoo and hair care products targeted at a young teenage female audience. The products are positioned as fun, stylish, “must-have” items aimed at encouraging young girls (12-17 years old) to get into a regular hair care routine.

Company C:  Nice Ice is a chain of ice cream cafes targeted at teenagers and their parents. Positioned as a trendy place to hang out with friends, the chain plans to open 25 outlets in large towns within a year.

Company D:  Green-Phone is a new brand of smart phone positioned as sustainable. It is targeted at consumers who need to replace their phone whilst reducing their impact on the environment. The company’s marketing objective is to seize a 10% market share in the mobile phone market in year 1 by building awareness and trial rapidly.

Key elements of a Company Briefing Paper

Please note that this is an indicative list only of what should be included in your work, it is not a running order or list of contents: thus, the logic and flow of material is up to you to decide.

Introduction to the paper (what is the purpose of the paper and what it will cover?)
Critical analysis and discussion of academic theory in your chosen topic area. You should aim to focus your discussion on any issue that you consider to be of relevance/ importance/ interest – but – be careful to scope it in. Do not be tempted to cover too many issues.  Remember, your aim is to offer a critical discussion, not to simply describe one article after another – thus, you should aim to go for depth rather than breadth. For example, is there an area of controversy or divided opinion in the subject area, e.g. where researchers have found different or conflicting results?
Examples – integrate practitioner sources to demonstrate how the issues raised in your review of the academic literature are used /applied in the case of at least two companies/ organisations/ brands in their marketing communications
Conclusions and recommendations: what conclusion do you draw from the review of the academic literature?  Based on this, what recommendations would you make to the Marketing Director of your chosen fictitious company?
References: ALL sources used in the work must be shown in accurate Harvard style, including the in-text citations and the Reference list at the end of the work.
Appendices are optional and should be used only if there is a need to include any supporting information.
Presentation style – your paper must be presented to professional standards and demonstrate a coherent structure.  It should include a title page, contents page, page numbers, and a clear system of appropriate headings and sub-headings.
 

Element 2 – Reflective statement on the research process

The Company Briefing Paper requires you to find, evaluate and use information drawn from a range of academic and practitioner sources. The ability to carry out information search and demonstrate reflective professional practice are important skills that employers are looking for.

For the reflective statement, therefore, you should write 200 words reflecting on your research process and the trustworthiness of the sources you have used. You should address:

How did you judge whether your sources were credible and reliable?
What did you learn from the research process in undertaking this assignment?
How might you take this learning forward into your professional life?
 The reflective statement should be inserted in a separate section at the very end of your Company Briefing Paper, after the references and any appendices, and NOT as a separate document.

Element 3 –Experts and Novices Roundtable Sessions

Five Roundtable Experts & Novices sessions in Teaching Block 2 take the form of expert and student-led, co-created workshops, where students take on the role of either an “Expert” or a “Novice” and work together to share and develop knowledge about the topics for the Company Briefing Paper.

Following from Element 1 above, your chosen literature review topic designates you as an “Expert” at the relevant roundtable session.  For the roundtable sessions where the topic is not your chosen literature review topic, you are a “Novice”.  Everyone will therefore be an “Expert” at one session and a “Novice” at the other four sessions.

Attendance at the Roundtable Expert and Novices workshop sessions is mandatory.

The purpose of the workshops is to develop subject knowledge and help you prepare for the assignment. You will also develop your research skills as well as gain confidence in your ability to explain the results of your research to others. Employers place high importance on communication and listening skills, and the Experts and Novices sessions will enable you to practice and hone your talents in both areas.  

In preparation for the workshops you are required to find and read at least four academic journal papers on your chosen literature review topic and prepare a written summary of your findings in the form of a Thematic Analysis Grid (TAG). 

The Critical Thinking module on Canvas provides resources to help you produce your TAG, and enrolment on the module is recommended:  https://canvas.kingston.ac.uk/courses/7439

This means actively participating in the workshops and coming prepared, i.e. having done the reading and produced the required TAG preparation paper. Specifically:

Experts must find and read at least four academic journal articles* in their chosen topic area and prepare a written summary of these articles in the form of a fully-referenced Thematic Analysis Grid (TAG). In your designated Expert workshop session, you will use your TAG paper as the basis for your explanation about your topic to a small group of Novices.
Experts must also find examples of how brands/companies have used/ applied the theory in practice, to illustrate your findings to your Novices.
Novices must read the relevant content in Fill & Turnbull (2019) or at least ONE academic journal article in order to gain a basic understanding of the topic AND find examples to discuss in class. Be ready to ask questions of your Expert.
During the roundtable sessions, after the Experts have shared their findings with the Novices, Experts and Novices will work together to apply the theory to a practical scenario and produce recommendations for practice.
At the end of every roundtable both Experts and Novices are required to complete a Contribution Sheet that reflects on your input into the sessions and what you got out of them. You must submit a satisfactory Contribution Sheet in order to gain your marks for each workshop roundtable.

title: risk and crisis management
description:
BUSM117 2023 Coursework assignment Instructions and guidance
The coursework assignment is worth 40% of the total mark for this module.
Sources
For both the coursework assignment and for the examination, you must ONLY use the literature listed in the reading lists in this module handbook for all conceptual and theoretical points.
For your case studies, however, you may use other peer-reviewed sources or other reputable, well-researched sources.
Do not use practitioner web sites as sources for your assessments.
Word limit
Marks may be deducted if you overshoot the word limit. For the sake of clarity, unlike on some modules there is no percentage allowance for excess words: the limit is 2000 words exactly. (For the sake of clarity, unlike on some modules there is no percentage allowance for excess words: the limit is 2000 words exactly.)
This does not include reference lists and bibliographies although citations in the main body of your assignment do count. The words in the question itself, which will be your title, do not count against the word limit.
Do not include a summary at the beginning of the essay, as well as your introduction: that would count against the word limit, and you would risk a deduction of marks for repetition.
Do not use appendices: they would also count against the word limit and in any case the evidence supporting your argument should be in the main body of your essay.
Guidance on the coursework assignments
1. To answer any of the coursework questions, you will need to draw upon your learning from the seminars. You should expect to use examples which you examined in preparatory study for and in discussion during the seminars for this module.
2. Use and compare two or three case studies to illustrate and support your arguments. You can draw cases from the articles and books suggested in the reading lists, in particular from the reading lists for the seminar tasks. Supplement the information on these cases by searching using the QMUL library, to find additional peer reviewed articles and also look for major investigative reports.
3. Don’t just describe. Focus your answer on causal processes which explain the outcomes for risk management which you want to argue in, in response to the specific question set.
4. Ensure that your answer draws on material covered week 1-8 of the module.
Coursework questions
Select one of the following three questions and write an essay of not more than 2000 words in answer to it.
1. Enterprise risk management: Assess the evidence for and the limitations of the main arguments made by at least three advocates and by at least three critics of enterprise risk management (ERM). In particular, assess the evidence for their rival claims about its

practicality in implementation, effectiveness and capacity to limit the effect of bias, for different kinds of businesses and organisations, for different kinds of risks, and for different phases of the business cycle.
Support your analysis of the strengths and weakness of the advocates’ and the critics’ cases by comparing either cases of attempts to implement ERM either in (a) two contrasting industries or (b) in two firms of very different sizes.
2. Risk perception / communication: Under what conditions and with what risk communication strategies, if any, can companies succeed in reassuring consumers who are sceptical of the safety of a company’s products or services and local residents living or working near a company’s hazardous site or plant or operations?
Support your analysis by comparing evidence about conditions for success and strategies from two industries, one of which should be concerned with risk communication to consumers about product or service safety and the other with risk communication to local residents about operational safety. Both cases should concern routine business work, not crisis or post-crisis conditions. Identify key differences and similarities between these contexts.
3. Project risk in mega-projects: Why does the implementation of project risk management procedures so often fail to reduce project risks in mega-projects? Review empirical evidence from research and assess the relative importance of at least four different factors.
Support your analysis by comparing cases of more and less successful mega-projects, where risk management procedures were implemented in each case, even in the less successful project.
General advice
- Answer the exact question set.
- Structure your essay carefully, with a clear introduction that ‘signposts’ the sequence of the argument to be made out, a main body of argument, and a conclusion which integrates the whole argument.
- Support your answer with carefully marshalled, ordered and sequenced presentations of empirical evidence, setting out your reasons for answer to the question in full.
- Use empirical cases and evidence to illustrate your argument.
- Use the literature in the field critically.
- Define and explain key concepts when you introduce them.
Common mistakes to avoid
1. Being vague – e.g., failing to define key terms, writing obscurely, failing to be clear and unambiguous.
2. Over-claiming – claiming too much, claiming more than your evidence really supports.
3. Asserting rather than arguing – failing to support your claims with empirical evidence
and logically related reasons.
4. Swithering – arguing for one answer to the question set in one part of the essay and
then arguing for a quite different or even opposite answer in another part of the essay.
5. Being indecisive – writing a ‘on the one hand ... and on the other ...’ answer to the
question set that does not come down clearly in favour of one answer to it.
6. Not considering the limitations of at least one opposing case, if only briefly.

7. Presenting a conclusion that does not follow from the argument or the evidence.
8. Trying to rely on knowledge drawn from other modules.
9. Writing without a well-thought out structure – e.g., no evident and logical sequence of
points that build up to a step-by-step argument to a conclusion.
10. Being uncritical and not being thoughtful – e.g., taking the conventional ‘textbook’
wisdom for granted, without interrogating it, without examining whether the evidence
supports it.
11. Summarising – just summarising what leading authors have written, without making an
argument of your own.
12. Writing about the topic rather than answering the exact question set.
13. Being too simple – e.g., assuming practice will mechanically follow rules set in laws or
objectives of programmes, taking simple abstract and theoretical differences between
industries for granted, over-generalising about fields.
14. Presenting your essay poorly – e.g., writing illegibly, not making your paragraph breaks clear and
obvious, not numbering and indenting key points in those cases where this would be helpful to the reader in understanding some steps in your argument.
Format
▪ All work must be typed and submitted in MS Word or Adobe PDF format
▪ Font size should be 12 point (unless otherwise specified)
▪ Font style should be Arial
▪ Lines should be double-spaced
▪ Leave margins for comment Insert page numbers
▪ Use a header containing your student ID number, the module code to which your work
applies, and the date
▪ Always spell-check and proof read your work before handing it in (once you have
submitted your work you will not be permitted to retrieve it)
▪ Keep your own electronic back-up copy of your work and if possible save on two
devices
▪ Avoid plagiarism
▪ Submit your work on time
Late submissions
1. Coursework submitted late (and there are no extenuating circumstances) will incur a late penalty. Five per cent of the total marks available shall be deducted for every period of 24 hours, or part thereof, that an assignment is overdue there shall be a deduction of five per cent of the total marks available (i.e. five marks for an assessment marked out of 100). After seven calendar days (168 hours or more late) the mark shall be reduced to zero, and recorded as 0FL (zero, fail, late).
2. Each module has word limits for coursework assignments; however, the decision about whether to impose a penalty mark for exceeding the word limit is made by each module organiser. You must check the module handbook and the assignment briefing documents to see whether the particular module organiser has adopted a penalty system. It is your responsibility to read the handbook and assignment briefing carefully. If no penalty is specified then the module organiser will take into account the word length under the standard marking conventions. For example, if you have exceeded the word limit then it might be that you have not been sufficiently succinct or focused in your assignment and therefore might be penalised for these weaknesses. Please note that word limits do NOT

3. 4.
5.
6. 7.
8.
include references or appendices. However if excessive material is included on appendices then this too will be judged accordingly and you may be awarded a lower mark.
You should ensure that your submission is in either Microsoft Word or PDF format. Failure to submit in either one of these formats will result in a mark of 0 being awarded for the particular assessment. It is therefore your responsibility to ensure that the file format is correct and it can be opened by the receiving party.
You should ensure that the correct piece of assignment is uploaded as the document downloaded on the due date by the module organiser will be marked regardless of content. You will not have another opportunity to submit the work again if you mistakenly uploaded the wrong document.
ALLOW YOURSELF PLENTY OF TIME TO SUBMIT YOUR COURSEWORK. DO NOT LEAVE IT UNTIL THE LAST MINUTE
Computer problems, such as computer viruses, failure to make a back-up copy or temporary internet access problems, will NOT be viewed as a valid reason for late submission.
Check that your assignment submission has been successful, and print a copy of the confirmation screen.
If you

The marking criteria for the coursework assignment and for the examination are the same. They are set out in the following table, which you will also see used to provide feedback on your assignment and to explain the mark given. For both the coursework assignment and for the examination, you must ONLY use the literature listed in the reading lists in this module handbook for all conceptual and theoretical points. For your case studies, however, you may use other peer-reviewed sources or other reputable, well-researched sources. Do not use practitioner web sites as sources for your assessments.
