title: Report
description:
Tag sheet is already done.
Topic sponsorship. 
Artcile links are below 

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0148296309000290#preview-

https://www.jisc.ac.uk/core

https://core.ac.uk/download/pdf/38024379.pdf

https://www.researchgate.net/publication/239781417





Overview

You will choose one Marketing Communication topic out of a list of five, topic in which you will become an ‘expert’ by researching a range of sources. You will write up an up-to-date, critical review of the academic literature in your chosen topic area, as well as some recommendations to a fictitious company (to be chosen from a list of four) on how this company should take the issues raised in your briefing paper into account in their 
future marketing communications.

The individual assignment comprises of three elements:

1. A fully-referenced Company Briefing Paper (2,000 words maximum)

2. A reflective statement on the research process (200 words maximum)

3. Preparation for and contribution to five “Experts and Novices” roundtables, including a TAG (Thematic Analysis Grid). 

 The task

Element 1 – Company Briefing Paper

You should choose one of the topics below as the subject of 2,000 words (maximum) fully-referenced Company Briefing Paper. Your chosen topic designates you as an “Expert” at the relevant Roundtable Experts & Novices workshop sessions (see Element 3 below).

Please note that a limited number of places will be available for each topic, therefore you should choose a secondary topic as a back-up. A topic sign-up list will be available on Canvas closer to the time.

· Brand placement

· Sponsorship

· Ethics in Marketing Communications

· Customer Journey Communications

· Interactive/Digital & mobile communications

 

The Company Briefing Paper must be written in the 3rd person and provide the Marketing Director of a fictitious company (see below for choice of companies) with the following:

An up-to-date, critical review of the academic literature in your chosen topic area
drawing on an absolute minimum of two carefully selected academic journal 
articles and on a range of at least ten diverse sources. 
Integrate into your discussion at least two examples of how the academic theory reviewed is used/ applied by brands/ companies in current practice. Here, you should draw on practitioner sources such as the trade press (e.g. Marketing Week), newspaper articles (e.g. The Guardian) and news sources (e.g. BBC), and blogs, articles and websites written by credible industry commentators and experts. 
Recommendations for how the fictitious company should take the issues raised in your briefing paper into account in their future marketing communications.
In this way, your Company Briefing Paper will pull together the academic literature on a topic with examples drawn from marketing practice. Employers put a high value on candidates who can demonstrate skills in critical thinking, synthesising (bringing together) material from different sources, and analysing complex material.

 

You should choose any ONE of the fictitious companies shown below as the focal company for your Company Briefing Paper. 

Company A: Get Fit Now is a new pay-as-you go gym, targeting consumers who have become disillusioned by high joining and membership fees of health clubs. As a newcomer they need to build awareness very quickly and ensure that potential customers understand their position in the market place. 

Company B: Bio-gloss is a brand of shampoo and hair care products targeted at a young teenage female audience. The products are positioned as fun, stylish, “must-have” items aimed at encouraging young girls (12-17 years old) to get into a regular hair care routine.

Company C: Nice Ice is a chain of ice cream cafes targeted at teenagers and their parents. Positioned as a trendy place to hang out with friends, the chain plans to open 25 outlets in large towns within a year.

Company D: Green-Phone is a new brand of smart phone positioned as sustainable. It is targeted at consumers who need to replace their phone whilst reducing their impact on the environment. The company’s marketing objective is to seize a 10% market share in the mobile phone market in year 1 by building awareness and trial rapidly.

Key elements of a Company Briefing Paper

Please note that this is an indicative list only of what should be included in your work, it is not a running order or list of contents: thus, the logic and flow of material is up to you to decide.

Introduction to the paper (what is the purpose of the paper and what it will cover?)
Critical analysis and discussion of academic theory in your chosen topic area. You should aim to focus your discussion on any issue that you consider to be of relevance/ importance/ interest – but – be careful to scope it in. Do not be tempted to cover too many issues. Remember, your aim is to offer a critical discussion, not to simply describe one article after another – thus, you should aim to go for depth rather than breadth. For example, is there an area of controversy or divided opinion in the subject area, e.g. where researchers have found different or conflicting results?
Examples – integrate practitioner sources to demonstrate how the issues raised in your review of the academic literature are used /applied in the case of at least two companies/ organisations/ brands in their marketing communications
Conclusions and recommendations: what conclusion do you draw from the review of the academic literature? Based on this, what recommendations would you make to the Marketing Director of your chosen fictitious company?
References: ALL sources used in the work must be shown in accurate Harvard style, including the in-text citations and the Reference list at the end of the work.
Appendices are optional and should be used only if there is a need to include any supporting information.
Presentation style – your paper must be presented to professional standards and demonstrate a coherent structure. It should include a title page, contents page, page numbers, and a clear system of appropriate headings and sub-headings.
 

Element 2 – Reflective statement on the research process

The Company Briefing Paper requires you to find, evaluate and use information drawn from a range of academic and practitioner sources. The ability to carry out information search and demonstrate reflective professional practice are important skills that employers are looking for.

For the reflective statement, therefore, you should write 200 words reflecting on your research process and the trustworthiness of the sources you have used. You should address:

How did you judge whether your sources were credible and reliable?
What did you learn from the research process in undertaking this assignment?
How might you take this learning forward into your professional life?
 The reflective statement should be inserted in a separate section at the very end of your Company Briefing Paper, after the references and any appendices, and NOT as a separate document.

 

Element 3 –Experts and Novices Roundtable Sessions

Five Roundtable Experts & Novices sessions in Teaching Block 2 take the form of expert and student-led, co-created workshops, where students take on the role of either an “Expert” or a “Novice” and work together to share and develop knowledge about the topics for the Company Briefing Paper.

Following from Element 1 above, your chosen literature review topic designates you as an “Expert” at the relevant roundtable session. For the roundtable sessions where the topic is not your chosen literature review topic, you are a “Novice”. Everyone will therefore be an “Expert” at one session and a “Novice” at the other four sessions.

Attendance at the Roundtable Expert and Novices workshop sessions is mandatory.

The purpose of the workshops is to develop subject knowledge and help you prepare for the assignment. You will also develop your research skills as well as gain confidence in your ability to explain the results of your research to others. Employers place high importance on communication and listening skills, and the Experts and Novices sessions will enable you to practice and hone your talents in both areas. 

In preparation for the workshops you are required to find and read at least four academic journal papers on your chosen literature review topic and prepare a written summary of your findings in the form of a Thematic Analysis Grid (TAG). 

The Critical Thinking module on Canvas provides resources to help you produce your TAG, and enrolment on the module is recommended: https://canvas.kingston.ac.uk/courses/7439

Given the co-created nature of these sessions, their success depends entirely on everyone taking responsibility for their part in the sessions and the impact of this on others. This means actively participating in the workshops and coming prepared, i.e. having done the reading and produced the required TAG preparation paper. Specifically:

Experts must find and read at least four academic journal articles* in their chosen topic area and prepare a written summary of these articles in the form of a fully-referenced Thematic Analysis Grid (TAG). In your designated Expert workshop session, you will use your TAG paper as the basis for your explanation about your topic to a small group of Novices.
Experts must also find examples of how brands/companies have used/ applied the theory in practice, to illustrate your findings to your Novices.
Novices must read the relevant content in Fill & Turnbull (2019) or at least ONE academic journal article in order to gain a basic understanding of the topic AND find examples to discuss in class. Be ready to ask questions of your Expert.
During the roundtable sessions, after the Experts have shared their findings with the Novices, Experts and Novices will work together to apply the theory to a practical scenario and produce recommendations for practice.
At the end of every roundtable both Experts and Novices are required to complete a Contribution Sheet that reflects on your input into the sessions and what you got out of them. You must submit a satisfactory Contribution Sheet in order to gain your marks for each workshop roundtable.

title: Range Architecture For Women's Youth Fashion Brand
description:
Project details- Range Architecture of Reliance Trends brand RIO. There are two sub-brands: RIO Girls (kidswear & teenage girls) , RIO (Women's wear). We have selected 2-2 product categories from both the sub-brands. From RIO Girls- Tops & Bottoms (Denim Jeans) and from RIO - Tops & Bottoms (Denim Jeans). The biggest competitor of RIO brand is MAX Fashion. There are 2 inspirational brand of RIO, i.e., HnM & Zara. 
Now, we have to do a survey regarding brand RIO. Questionnaire and its responses are ready. Only the conclusion needs to be made out from the survey responses with charts and graphs. I'll be attaching the questionnaire and responses for your reference.
Next, we need to do a in-depth analysis of brand RIO (including sub-brands) and MAX Fashion (basically a in-depth competitor analysis) with figures, charts and graphs. And analysis of inspirational brand also.
Then, we have to do a in-depth product analysis of both these brands (products chosen mentioned above) including the fabric, style, fit, trim, embroidery, silhouette, etc.
Mention the product range for both the brand (RIO &MAX) with product images.
Next, we have to do a gap analysis for these brands ( like what MAX Fashion is doing which brand RIO is not) and to find the recommendation and solutions. What all we can incorporate in brand RIO so that the structure of the brand is improved and its sales increases.

title: Reflection Paper
description:
Critically analyse a news item, a documentary, or a movie in about 1500 words using the concepts discussed as part of the course. Critically engage the chosen movie, documentary, or news item using at least ONE text that is part of the syllabus. Do NOT pick a news item or any audio-visual material that has already been discussed in class. 
A good essay will show a concise and clear interpretation of the material, a thorough and critical engagement with the concept and the text as well as clarity in thinking and writing. Use of sub-headings is encouraged as it helps in organising the material in an essay.

title: Research Paper
description:
Based on any one of the films (taste of cherry by Abbas Kiarostam) prescribed in the syllabus or Arthur Miller’s play The Crucible – along with the help of secondary sources, the students are expected to write a research/academic essay.
The research paper must engage with a primary text (film or play), along with at least five (5) secondary sources (at least 3 print sources from JSTOR, Project Muse, etc. and 2 credible online sources). The essay should consist of an Introduction (including the thesis statement), main body of the essay (no limit to the number of paragraphs you could write), and a conclusion. The research paper must demonstrate research and follow the Thesis-Evidence-Evaluation model.
The secondary sources are meant to either support your argument or to be used as a counterargument. In any case, it is better to use them as enabling evidence. Your own voice must not be drowned out by the secondary sources, that is, your paper should not become a mere repetition and summing up of the claims in the secondary sources. You may either quote directly some lines from the secondary sources or sum up their ideas.
Whether you quote directly or sum up the main ideas in secondary sources, you must cite them in your essay. Otherwise, it will be an act of plagiarism, which will invite severe reprimand in the form of failing or deducting marks.
The essay must follow either MLA or Chicago style guide for both in-text citations and Works Cited/Reference guidelines.  
Credits will be given for originality and creativity.

title: People Planet Profit
description:
PEOPLE PLANET PROFIT [Report]
Minimum word count: 3000 [extra 10% allowed]
Minimum references: 30
Arial: 11, line spacing: 1.5 
Table of content required 
Sources for references: Hub(Proquest, Ebsco), UNWTO, Tourism site of the destination.

According to the UNWTO (2021), “the future resilience of tourism will depend on the sector’s ability to embrace a low carbon pathway and cut emissions by 50% by 2030”.

Question: Critically discuss this statement and evaluate the main challenges of such a significant reduction in emissions by 2030 from a destination perspective.

IPCC Report Climate Change 2021: The Physical Science Basis - https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg1/ 


INDICATIVE ANSWER 1

1 INTRODUCTION 
1.1 Definition (1 or 2 max), History and Evolution of Sustainability 
1.2 Definition (1 or 2 max), Overview of Sustainable Tourism Development [can add few points from SDG]
(Total 300 words) 

2 DESTINATION- for eg. Mumbai, Maharashtra, India. [Can be any destination but preferably from a developing or Asian country, or Islands, Tip- Write the entire official name of the place eg. Republic of India] [You can add maps of the destination in the appendices]
2.1 Introduce the choice of your tourism destination, and history in 1/2 lines. [Mention the statistics of GDP from tourism, their graphs can go in the appendices.]
2.2 What are carbon emissions. Highlight the sources of carbon emission in tourism with relation to your choice of destination. Then which industry in that particular destination emits the maximum carbon? [Greenhouse gases other than CO2 can be mentioned if global warming is being discussed as a larger picture but in 1-2 sentences]
For example, in a country; the destination could be a tourist attraction such as a heritage site, place of interest that tourists visit for: 
1. landscape and culture and/or events
 2. architecture,
 3. gastronomy, 
4. infrastructure development and transport, 
5. lodging (accommodation),
 6. shopping 
Choose any 2 of the above-stated components which will be common for all the 3 pillars.
2.3 Short introduction about the two components [Also mention how the components are creating an impact on the destination]
 (Total 300 words)

 3 THREE PILLARS OF SUSTAINABILITY [Definition of each pillar must be given, and then both the components need to be mentioned with reference to the pillar, it can be mentioned 1 after another or combined whatever is suitable, and positive as well as negative impacts for both components must be discussed related to the particular pillar] 
3.1 Economic Sustainability – Concept, definition (1/2 max) (300 words) 
3.1.1 Two Positive Aspects/Impact (Should be discussed in the context of carbon emissions) – Related to the 2 components which you have selected. [Support it with statistics regarding emissions]
3.1.2 Two Negative Aspects/Impact (Should be discussed in the context of carbon emissions) – Related to the 2 components which you have selected.
This is to be linked and integrated with the chosen destination 
3.1.3 Barriers that impact its practical implementation 
Add examples under each 3.1.1; 3.1.2; 3.1.3. [Another country’s data can be used in examples for your 3 pillars like how they reduced emissions and their technique can be used as a solution in our case]
Theory (for eg. Ice burg, product life cycle, Maslow’s hierarchy) / Processes / Models should be added which contribute to the sustainable development of the chosen destination. For eg., If an accommodation component is taken then processes such as 3R can be used, or rainwater harvesting, faucets, and nozzles which save water. [At least in 2 pillars theories needs to be added and link the theory to one of the components of the pillar and related images can go in the appendices]
(500 words) 

3.2 Social Sustainability (300 words) 
3.2.1 Positive aspect/impact
 3.2.2 Negative aspect/impact 
3.2.3 Barriers that impact its practical implementation 
(500 words)

 3.3 Environmental Sustainability (300 words) 
3.3.1 Positive aspect/impact
 3.3.2 Negative aspect/impact 
3.3.3 Barriers that impact its practical implementation
 (500 words)

 4 CONCLUSION AND RECOMMENDATIONS FOR THE TOURISM INDUSTRY 
[Minimum 3 recommendations without citations and reference list and it has to be unique]

5 REFERENCE LIST
 6 APPENDICES-Images related to statistics mentioned, maps of the selected destination, images of theories/processes used.  [With citations and reference list]

title: Tourism in developing countries
description:
TOURISM IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES [Essay]
Word count: 3500 [10% extra is allowed]
Required citations and reference list: 35
Introduction: 350
Conclusion: 350
Main body: 2800
The main body is further divided into 3 parts
Theme 01- 875 words
Theme 02- 875 words
Practical component-1050 words
(Support any theme with any developing country)

Themes for the essay (Have to select any two)
1] Ethics in tourism *
2] Community-based tourism
3]Eco-tourism
4]Volunteer tourism
5] Pro-poor tourism
6]Displacement tourism*
7] Post-disaster tourism*
8] Post-conflict tourism*
9]Power and political instability*
[The topics with * symbol have a lot of information on the hub therefore is a good option, but other topics if taken and provided with proper content and statistics might increase marks as they are uncommon]

Introduction:
-Tourism in developing economy
-Contribution of tourism to the GDP 
-Problems faced by the tourism
-Relationship between tourism and developing countries
-Why do we call them developing countries.  
Signposting required:- What your essay is all about,  mention both the themes and further about the country which you are taking in the practical component. (Can also mention the stakeholders [Tourist, government, host, chosen destination, investor].)

MAIN BODY:- 
THEME 01: Explain the concept, give the definition or quote anything.
{Critical discussion about all the stakeholders [Tourist, government, host, chosen destination, investor].}
For eg. Pros to the tourist, cons to the tourist, and cons because of the tourist, likewise, you have to discuss the pros, cons, and cons because of, about all the stakeholders 
2 Theories have to be mentioned in each theme – 1 will be major and 1 will be minor 
Going from one theme to another there should be connectivity. 

THEME 02: Similar to the above theme

PRACTICAL COMPONENT: Support any one theme with a developing country
	Introduction of the country 
	Location
	What all forms of tourism are included in the country 
	Contribution of tourism in developing countries
	Why tourism is getting affected
	GDP from tourism (statistics need to be mentioned)
	Efforts of the host population and the government for the development of the chosen country
	Mention any investors (who have invested in tourism of the developing country) if they’re from other countries 

THEORIES WHICH CAN BE USE:- (Even 10% of 875-word count for the theory is enough)
Major- 
	TALC (Tourist area life cycle) [can be used for stakeholder “destination”]
	Doxey’s theory   [can be used for stakeholder “ tourist”; “host”]
	Valene smith’s theory- Adaption of tourists to local norms [can be used for stakeholder “tourist”]
Minor-
	Multiplier effect [can be used for stakeholder “host population”, “host government”]
	Economic leakages [can be used for stakeholder “host population”, “host government”, “investor”]
{You can jump from one theory to another in the same discussion for better scores}
Demonstration effect or cultural exchange cannot be used as theories but are good points for discussion (in terms of socio-cultural impacts)

Aims
The module is designed to enable students to engage with the essential aspects of organisations and organisational behaviour. It will explore important contemporary issues of organisational life across a range of organisational contexts.
Learning Outcomes

title: Auction DApp
description:
I made a project on e-auction based on blockchain. It is T a decentralized app used for simulating an auction house.
The app contains functionalities for:

Creating auction
Participating in active auctions
Place private bids and reveal them after bidding time closes
Closing the auction by the organizer
Confirming the bids placed and declaring the winner
Delivering the item to the winner with confirmation
There are 4 types of auctions supported:

Market listing: A normal listing that remains public and active till the organizer closes the auction. The winner is the highest bidder.
Blind Auction: A type of sealed bid auction where the bids are private and the winner is the highest bidder.
Vickrey Auction: A type of sealed bid auction where the bids are private. The winner is the highest bidder but the price paid is the second-highest bid.
Average Price Auction: A type of sealed bid auction where the bids are private. The winner is the highest bidder but the price paid is the average of all bids.
The auctions are conducted through smart contracts written in Solidity and Metamask is used for client-side communication.

Actually, I have completed the smart contracts and web application but the transactions through MetaMask are not working this is one of the issues(the integration part to be precise).
And currently, the project is for random stuff and I want to make it specific for the auction of paintings for that I need to upload and preview painting images on the web app.
The compiler version is 0.6.12

To start app follow commands :
1) in a new terminal type 
      a) truffle develop
      b) migrate --reset
2) in a new terminal 
      a) cd client 
      b) npm install
      c) npm start

title: Strategic Brand Management assignment for Msc. Marketing course
description:
So, they are asking you to look at Royce Lingerie, a family-
owned British business, which is one of the organisations that recently approached OBBC.
Royce Lingerie is specialised in manufacturing wire-free bras that provide comfort and support 
for all women – whether they are buying for their teenage daughter, are pregnant or nursing, 
are looking for larger cup sizes, or have undergone breast or chest surgery. Royce is also 
committed to supporting the LGBTQ+ community by manufacturing bras, for example, for 
people who identify as transgender.
They never want to stand still because their markets are permanently evolving and changing. 
They always aim to be ahead of the competition and know what the ‘big picture’ changes and 
the important ‘zeitgeist’ trends are.
Therefore, OBBC is pitching now to help Royce Lingerie prepare for a future brand positioning
that takes latest broader societal trends as well as a comprehensive market analysis into 
account. Due to time constraints, OBBC decides for the initial pitch phase to focus
geographically on the UK market only. For more details, see www.royce-lingerie.co.uk
One of the key challenges is to attract new and younger target audiences without losing older 
loyal customers.
Your report needs to cover the following elements

 ANALYSIS: What is this brand about? What are the key meanings, manifestations 
and stakeholders of the brand? What does the ‘product’ portfolio currently look like? 
What are the brand’s current vision, mission and core values? What are the 
strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats? How is the brand currently 
positioned? Your analysis is expected to look at a variety of elements of the brand. 
This should include the brand’s IDEOLOGY, CAPABILITIES, 
CONSUMERS/STAKEHOLDERS, COMPETITION and ENVIRONMENT. 
Mark allocation: 30%
 
STRATEGY: Based on your analysis, you are expected to discuss two different 
potential future positioning options for the brand which could be established in the UK 
market in autumn/winter 2023. You then need to justify/evaluate which of the 
discussed positionings has the most potential, i.e. you need to choose one 
positioning option and justify your decision. You can extend a positioning strategy 
that already exists, but you need to justify why this is the best option. Finally, you are 
expected to make suggestions as to how the brand positioning idea could be 
transformed into strategic frameworks that can be used to brief the client’s marketing 
team who need to bring this positioning idea to life. In this context you must apply 
one or more of the following frameworks: (a) SBM Vision, Mission & Values; (b) SBM 
Brand Pyramid; and/or (c) Transformation Grid. 
Mark allocation: 30%

 IMPLEMENTATION: Based on your strategic framework(s), you need to develop 
and explain implementation activities to show how, for example, the client’s UK 
marketing team could implement the core strategic idea which you have developed
with different specific stakeholders. This needs to contain an activity in terms of co-
creative new product development. One implementation activity needs to utilise 
social media-based communications or other latest digital technology. 
Mark allocation: 30%
The remaining 10% are allocated for the quality of the presentation of the assignment. This 
means, for example, overall presentation style; standard of English; breadth, depth, and 
quality of sources; references list presented in Harvard Referencing Style; word count well 
used.
You are required to produce a report comprising the three key areas outlined above. You 
must support your decisions with academic references as well as other secondary sources. 
Therefore, you must search for and use relevant information on the brand, but you are NOT 
expected to conduct primary empirical research as part of the assignment.

Must not contact the client at all.
The information shared here needs to be 100% confidential or I'll get in big trouble as this is an actual client not a fictional one just for the assignment.

title: Global business environment
description:
Choose ONE of the four assignment topics below.
Topic 1: Select a multinational firm operating in a foreign country—for instance, Tesla in China
1) Analyse how key factors in the two dimensions of the business environment (e.g., political and technological) influence the competitive forces in the two dimensions of the industry where the selected firm is operating (e.g., threat of new entrants, bargaining power of customers).
2) Discuss the past strategies of the firm that respond to the opportunities and threats arising from those environmental changes and suggest the future strategies of the firm.
OR
Topic 2: Select a digital platform firm which is born global—for instance, AirBnB
1) Analyse the disruptive effects of digital technology on the global industry boundary where the selected firm is operating in the three analytical dimensions (i.e., competitors/complementors/customers).
2) Discuss the firm’s platform AND global strategies that respond to the opportunities and threats arising from these disruptive changes.
OR
Topic 3: Select two competitor firms. One is a catch-up firm from emerging economies and the other is an incumbent firm from advanced economies (e.g., Huawei and Ericsson)
1) Analyse the effects of globalisation AND digitalisation on the industry where the selected firms are competing.
1

2) Compare and discuss the selected firms’ catch-up AND defensive strategies that respond to the opportunities and challenges arising from the effects of globalisation and digitalisation.
OR
Topic 4: Select a global firm that operates in multiple countries (e.g., TikTok)
1) Analyse the causes underpinning the rise of the technonationalism around the world in recent years.
2) Discuss how the rise of the technonationalism has affected the firm’s global strategies to operate in foreign countries (e.g., the selection of international markets and partners). Also suggest the firm’s future strategy to manage potential risks arising from those challenges (e.g., international standardisation and localisation).

title: Management issues and controversies
description:
Management Issues and Controversies MGT5264
Coursework Briefing
(Individual, written)
 
Course Code
MGT5264
Course Title
Management Issues and Controversies
Course Coordinator
Josephine Adekola
Coursework format
Individual assignment
Weighting
75.00%
Word limit
2,500 words
(+/- 10%) Refer to word limit policy
Action to be taken if word limit is exceeded
Exceeding word limit precludes award of an A.
Submission date
23 December 2022
Release date to students
15 January 2023
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Intended Learning Outcomes being assessed
 
By the end of this course students will be able to:
1. Understand and explain the differences between shareholder and stakeholder capitalism as well as alternative approaches found in mixed or non-capitalist economies.
2. Identify the most intensely controversial aspects of contemporary management and leadership.
3. Explain the significance of contextual conditions, and especially the impact of organizational and environmental turbulence on management issues and controversies.

TASK 2:
Report: 2,500 words – 75% weighting. 
Using any analytical framework of your choice, identify three top management controversial issues facing an organization of your choice. Set out a management plan to manage or mitigate the controversial issue within the selected organisation.
 
 
Assessment criteria
This assignment invites students to think about the relative importance of different sections of the management. The are no “right” or “wrong” choices, but what is very important is the argument presented to justify the choices provided. This assignment is intended to establish a benchmark for each student to compare and contrast their view at the start and upon completion of the class.
 
  
Course Rubric
Please note that this rubric is intended to inform the marking process and NOT be a definitive guide to any final grade which is, in essence, based on the academic judgement of the marker.
Criteria
Excellent/Very Good B-A Grade
Good C grade
Satisfactory
D1-D2 Grade
Weak-Poor
D3, F-E Grade
Contents/Materials
- Quality of contents
- Depth and relevance of Refection
- Level of individuality
- Self-critical analysis
- Connections between concepts and examples.
Very deep, honest and critical reflection that uses specific and convincing examples from personal experience to make and support claims.
Strong evidence of learning that links clearly to a well set-out development plan and specific areas for changes/ improvement of future performance.
Self-critical analysis is articulated, and brings out specific personal insights from the experience.  
Strong applicable connections shown between relevant concepts and examples.
 
Deep reflection with clear relevant examples from personal experience to support claims.
Very good evidence of learning that is linked to a development plan for changes and improvement.
Good level of self-critical analysis with personal insights drawn.
Shows good evidence in the connection between concepts and examples.
The reflection is largely relevant and reasonable deep with some examples provided to support claims.
Some evidence of learning with consequences for actions mentioned.
Some evidence of a personal development plan with self-critical analysis though falls short in details.
Make clear attempt in integrating concepts and examples.
The reflection is mostly irrelevant to the project, or it merely scratches the surface with inadequate or vague examples that only partially support claims.
More of a report/ description of events and activities than a self-reflection.
Limited evidence of self-critical analysis (e.g. of own knowledge, assumptions/ stereotypes, and actions; and of the literature drawn upon).
Limited evidence of learning and its connection to personal development plan.
Weak connections between concepts and examples.
 
Structure, Formatting and Presentation
- Written in first person
- Concise writing
- Absence of typographical and grammatical errors
- Legibility, structure and flow of text
Contents are very professionally laid out and formatted.
Structure is clear with precise sectioning; and the flow of contents is logical and coherent.
Articulated first-person narrative.
Writing is precise, sophisticated and engaging to read.
Shows clear evidence of care and attention to avoid typos and grammatical errors.
 
Contents are clearly structured and sectioned into a coherent flow.
Written in first person narrative.
Writing is succinct and sentences are mostly structured effectively.
Shows evidence of care and attention to avoid typos and grammatical errors.
 
Contents are appropriately structured, and flow of thoughts could be followed and understood.
Mostly written in first person narrative.
Writing is reasonably clear.
Some minor typos and grammatical errors, but overall presentation is clear.
Contents are weakly structured and the flow disorganised.
Limited first-person narrative.
Writing is winding and redundant, and sentence structure is often confusing.
Shows little evidence of planning the layout and format, and of care to spot and correct typos or grammatical errors.

title: ANALYSIS OF THE OPERATIONS MANAGEMENT OF ADIDAS  in terms of Product Manufacturing and Distribution
description:
●	You must prepare and submit an original business report addressing the tasks identified later in this section, but summarised below.
●	Your report must analyse and evaluate the operations management of an organisation, or of a specific business unit/division, and draw conclusions over the extent to which its operational capability supports its corporate strategy and provides competitive advantage.

The Organisation:
You must select one focal organisation as the subject of your assignment. Where the organisation has different divisions or a disparate product/service offer, you may have to select one specific area of the organisation for study (i.e., you will need to define the scope to be covered in your report). You may also find it appropriate to select by geographical region, or if the organisation has disparate operations, one of these.
 
The organisation selected should meet the following criteria:
●	It should be a well-known business – you will find more data/information on large well-known businesses;
●	It must have a website that is available in English and produce annual reports in English;
●	It is recommended that your selected company be publicly listed/publicly traded on the stock market – you will find more data/information available on such organisations.

The Content of the Assignment:
You are required to demonstrate your learning from the course material by analysing and evaluating the operations management of your chosen organisation (or business unit/division) in a report containing the following sections.
 
1.	A brief introduction to the organisation, including an overview of the environment in which it operates and the pressures that its sector faces. This will give the reader sufficient context to make sense of the report.
 
2.	An analysis of the operations of the selected organisation – you must apply the transformation process model and the 4Vs model (and consider the implications) to your selected organization and their operations. In addition to this you should select two further topics/concepts covered in the module or from your wider reading (relating to operations management) this might be (as appropriate to the organisation) – performance objectives and current performance, the types of operating process, the service concept (what the operations systems are designed to deliver), location and layout, capacity management, the scheduling and control of resources, supply chain management, quality assurance or the application of TQM principles, the application of ‘lean’ principles.

This section is likely to represent the largest part of the Report and it is for you to decide which concepts/theories/models you include in this section.
 
3.	The identification of the major strengths and weaknesses of the operation – achieved performance against required performance. From your analysis, you should also consider the extent to which the operations functions support the broader business strategy of the organisation, and the extent to which the organisation’s operations capability is used to create competitive advantage.

Presenting coursework for assessment:
Your assignment when submitted should not include your name – we use a system of anonymous marking to reduce the risk of any unconscious bias. 

The authentic and essential requirements for this piece of assessed work are:
●	The report must contain a reference list. All sources cited must be referenced in the report. The Harvard referencing system must be used. 
●	You must use at least 10 academic sources other than the set texts (and ideally substantially more). In addition to academic sources, you’re expected to utilise ‘other’ sources to provide information, data and insights into your selected organisation and its operations.
●	The assignment must be structured and presented as a formal business report.
●	Arial font size 12 is recommended for the main body/text.

The report length should not exceed 2,500 words.

title: Research proposal assignment
description:
You are required to complete a 3,000 word research proposal to demonstrate your ability to identify, analyse a research problem related to business and management, and to set out a plan for a research project to investigate that problem. The aim of this assessment is to enable you to develop and demonstrate your ability to: (a) diagnose a problem in business and management, (b) formulate research questions, determine how to answer these questions by drawing on the academic literature, identify and assess the potential of appropriate research methods and (e) plan a small-scale research project.
This report is among the most challenging assignments set during your M.Sc. programme. You should note that it is quite different from, and more challenging than, writing a conventional coursework essay-style paper. You are being asked to anticipate the issues that you will have to overcome in planning, conducting and reporting a small research project. The best research proposals are usually those produced by those students who have devoted considerable thought to the assignment before even beginning to write the proposal. It is not an assignment that can be left to the last minute.
Your choice of problem for the project proposal report does not commit you to that topic for your dissertation. You can just complete the report as a free-standing exercise in which you are assessed on your competences as indicated in your ability to analyse a problem, grasp the arguments and the evidence contained in the literature, devise a suitable research design and present it effectively. You are free to select a different topic for your dissertation if you so wish, although there are obvious advantages in sticking to a topic to which you have already given thought and invested some work. However, you must avoid cutting-and-pasting parts of the proposal into the dissertation. In other words, your assignment for this module and your dissertations should be different, otherwise your report might be flagged as self- plagiarism.

title: How consumers cope with the challenge of identity loss or change due to life transitions such as retirement, divorce, or migration and how this influences their consumption of nostalgic products and experiences in the future.
description:
You can use the social-self theory to explore how consumers seek to maintain or restore their sense of belonging and identity through consumption.

Using self-identity theory, identify and evaluate a contemporary societal challenge that is influencing the consumption behaviour of consumers. Develop conclusions from your evaluation. Use these conclusions to develop a ‘future imagination’ of how consumers and their behaviour will evolve in the future in response to this challenge, and how marketing will need to adapt to continue to engage with them.
Your evaluation must include a critical appraisal of self-identity theory to inform your arguments. Additionally you must include evidence of relevant changing consumption behaviours and predictions from relevant experts. You must develop your ‘future imagination’ from your conclusions. 
In addressing the above question, you are advised to make the following choices:
1)	Choose a specific consumer segment who engage in a specific consumption behaviour occurring in response to a societal challenge. You can phrase this as a problem or opportunity. 
2)	Focus on one consumer segment pertinent to your topic and country/sector choice. You should develop a profile of this segment, providing as much pertinent information as you can, e.g. using sociodemographics, psychographics. Please present visually or in table format, fully referenced.
3)	Focus on one country for your essay. Having this focus will make it a lot easier for you to identify and evaluate the evidence within the word limit specified.
4)	While you are required to use self-identity theory for your essay, you MUST focus on a specific concept, model or framework within it. For example, the self-concept model, social-self, pro-environmental self-identity, pro-social self-identity, body image, etc. Choose ONE of these. Do NOT include multiple identity frameworks/ models in your essay because this will undermine the depth of analysis you can achieve within the 3000 word count limit.
Once you make the above choices, you are required to investigate research evidence from academic articles, news from legitimate sources, industry reports etc. to critically analyse how consumer behaviour has changed in response to the societal issue you have identified. Building from this appraisal, you will explain, evaluate and apply your identity framework/model to your chosen issue. This will enable you to develop evidence-based analytical conclusions, from which you can create your future imagination.

You should draw on a good range of high quality academic and expert opinion sources to construct solid arguments for your paper. You should use relevant examples and data to support your claims. Ensure you fully reference all sources of information.
You are required to write a critique of transforming/transformed consumer behaviour, informed by contextual information, evidence and relevant theory. Your critique will involve you assessing varied data, ideas and scholarship from varied sources. Be adventurous in your searching but note the advice given to you on reputable sources. 
You must focus on one framework/model of identity theory in your essay. This will really help you to develop a stronger critical appraisal to show your understanding and critical thinking. 
You must choose only one country and one consumer segment. Within this country and segment, try to analyse your chosen CB transformation broadly and briefly. Then narrow down again to your chosen sector/industry/segment and again articulate this transformation. You now have an explanation that is country, sector and consumer specific. Now that you have this foundation, you can begin to build your academic arguments by integrating your chosen identity theory. Continuously, apply and evaluate your theory to your country/sector/segment otherwise your context and theory risk being disconnected. Lastly, extrapolate your conclusions to a 5-10 year future in order to imagine how consumers and their behaviour will evolve in the future in response to this challenge, and how marketing will need to adapt to continue to engage with them. 
You must ensure the evidence you use to compile your paper relates to your choices (i.e. do not use American evidence to discuss China!). Preliminary reading will help you to make your choices. Whatever you choose to do, ensure you present your argument for your choices at the start of your paper – and justify them. 
Assemble the evidence for your arguments, avoid unsubstantiated statements and bias - this is an objective investigation. It is essential that you critique your chosen theory and evidence, do not just describe it; evaluate the contribution it makes to our understanding of transforming/transformed consumer behaviour and how marketing to consumers (as customers or event participants) will evolve as a result in the future.

GUIDELINES:
Part 1: Introduction and Explanation (500-800 words): Introduce and examine your societal challenge, consumer segment and behaviour and country. Explain the issue clearly and its impact, citing supporting evidence and justify why it is worthy of exploration in your essay. Include a profile of your chosen consumer segment.
Part 2: Evaluation and application of theoretical framework (1500-1800 words): Begin by giving an overview of identity theory, then focus on your chosen identity framework/model. Explain it and apply it to you challenge and context in part 1. Evaluate its contribution in explaining the CB transformation that is occurring, using scholarly research and evidence to support your arguments. Use examples throughout, pertinent to your focus. Images and illustrations can be used and add value to written arguments. 
Part 3: Conclusions (300-500 words): Develop conclusions based on your content in parts 1 and 2. Do not simply summarise your essay (this is not a conclusion). Your conclusions should be insightful and analytical and lead into your future appraisal. They should also demonstrate your learning from critically reviewing your chosen context and identity theory. Developing a ‘visual map’ to illustrate this can be a useful communication tool; this is entirely up to you. Examples are discussed in the assignment briefings and clinics. Keep your writing style concise and focused. Numbering each conclusion will be helpful for cross referencing with your future appraisal. You could also consider these as a map for part 4.
Part 4: The future (<500 words): This is where you get to be creative! Tell us, based on your analysis in part 1,2 and 3 your core ideas for imagining how consumers and their behaviour will evolve in the future in response to this challenge, and how marketing will need to adapt to continue to engage with them. Include specific examples of your chosen issue/segment/behaviour. You can present your ‘future imagination’ as text and visually (we are not expecting artwork from you). Visualisation is encouraged and can include multiple formats, e.g. drawing, photographs, and digital images. Infographics are useful, using free software that is readily available. Check permissions for using any images that are not your own (and reference them as instructed by the owners).   
Make sure your discussion of the future is connected and builds upon what you have stated in the body of your essay and is backed by evidence.
Please note: 
Parts 1 and 2 need to be fully and extensively referenced. 
Part 3 will contain some pertinent references to support your insight e.g. from futurism, but should not repeat the full range of references in your theory review. Remember conclusions represent your critical thinking built from your prior analysis which you have already referenced. 
Part 4 does not require references, albeit you may need to reference some futurism insights if you include them here instead of in your conclusion (either place is fine). This section is showcasing your critical and creative thinking.
The use of subheadings to break up the essay is OK, however, please ensure you don’t have too many as you risk hyper-fragmenting your essay, which may hamper the flow of discussion and subsequent analysis.

title: Managing Innovation in Entrepreneurial Organisations
description:
Coursework Detail (taken from Module Outline)
You will be asked to choose an entrepreneurial or an innovative organization which has been operating for a minimum of five years. This can be one you are interested in or a real-life company that you have access to – please speak to the module convenor prior to choosing your company for confirmation, if you are not sure that it meets the requirements.

 The coursework will audit and assess the innovative performance of your chosen organization – the main tool for the analysis will be the Diagnostic Framework of Entrepreneurial Practices (Mosey et al, 2017, p120), which will be covered in Session One. 

1. Explain whether existing capabilities of the organization can deliver appropriate types of innovation
2. Explain how the organization is structured and how it has supported or inhibited innovation
3. Explain how people are recruited and rewarded and how this supports or constrains innovation

4. Explain what organizational processes have been used to scan for ideas, select the most appropriate ones and provide resources to implement them

5. Explain how innovation challenges are identified
6. Explain how innovation is practised with external stakeholders
7. Explain how the organization manages uncertainty and failure
8. Explain how the organization reconciles exploratory and exploitative learning related to innovation performance

 There should be three sections to the report

1)   The analysis of the eight-core areas (in bold above) of the diagnostic framework (2000 words).

2)   The report should make appropriate recommendations for the future innovation strategy of your chosen organization (1000 words).

3)   The innovation strategy of your chosen organization in an international context (additional 1,000 words in a clearly separated section of the report)

 The report should cover these points with equal weighting.

 Reports which gain higher marks will:

provide evidence of reading around the topic and show a good understanding of the key concepts
include relevant theory and evidence and reference sources accurately.
critically discuss different viewpoints with arguments carefully developed and clearly expounded
show originality of thought
have good structure and clear presentation (including introductory and concluding sections)
make insightful and informed recommendations for the future

title: Research Methods for Management
description:
The research proposal requires you to demonstrate your ability to identify, analyse a research problem related to business and management, and to set out a plan for a research project to investigate that problem. The aim of this assessment is to enable you to develop and demonstrate your ability to: (a) diagnose a problem in business and management, (b) arrive at the consequent research questions, (c) determine how to answer these questions by drawing on the academic literature, (d) assess the potential of different research methods and (e) plan a small-scale research project.  
Your report is intended to form the plan for how you might use the literature (by drawing on the ideas and findings of others), design a research project and analyse the findings.  
This report is among the most challenging assignments set during the M.Sc. programmes. You are being asked to anticipate the issues that will confront you in conducting a small research project. Thus, it is quite different from and more difficult than, writing a conventional coursework paper. The best reports are usually those produced by those students who have devoted considerable thought to the assignment before even beginning to write the report.

title: Entrepreneurship
description:
What are the essay question choices?
Choose any 1 

1) Is ‘transformational leadership’ the most appropriate model of leadership for the
contemporary public and/or third sector(s)? Use a carefully selected case study to illustrate your answer and reflect on your own development as a current or future public and/or third sector leader.

2) Is ‘distributed leadership’ the most appropriate model of leadership for the contemporary public and/or third sector(s)? Use a carefully selected case study to illustrate your answer and reflect on your own development as a current or future public and/or third sector leader.

3) To what extent are private sector-derived models of strategic and performance management appropriate for public sector and/or third sector leaders? Use a carefully selected case study to illustrate your answer and reflect on your own development as a current or future public and/or third sector leader.

Case studies are factual and verifiable accounts of events (like ‘stories’). They do not provide us with definitive generalisable answers to questions, but provide rich, contextual insights. Case studies thereby help us to bring analytical arguments to life, and to avoid overly formulaic and theoretical responses to questions. [The classic text on using case studies in management is Robert K. Yin. (2014). Case Study Research Design and Methods (5th ed.). Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage.]

For this essay, cases should illustrate leadership in action during a specified period of change or reform in a particular organisational or sector (maybe in any country) and contain sufficient detail for you to convincingly describe a particular type of leadership practice and its outcomes for the organisation.

You can source your case studies from any verifiable and authoritative source, so long as they meet these conditions above. The sources may be online reports or articles, for example from leadership/public administration/voluntary sector journals, from government/NGO publications or sector-practitioner publications (see Module Outline for suggestions).

Then narrow down again to your chosen sector/industry/segment and again articulate this transformation. You now have an explanation that is country, sector and consumer specific. Now that you have this foundation, you can begin to build your academic arguments by integrating your chosen identity theory. Continuously, apply and evaluate your theory to your country/sector/segment otherwise your context and theory risk being disconnected. Lastly, extrapolate your conclusions to a 5-10 year future in order to imagine how consumers and their behaviour will evolve in the future in response to this challenge, and how marketing will need to adapt to continue to engage with them.
You must ensure the evidence you use to compile your paper relates to your choices (i.e. do not use American evidence to discuss China!). Preliminary reading will help you to make your choices. Whatever you choose to do, ensure you present your argument for your choices at the start of your paper – and justify them.
Assemble the evidence for your arguments, avoid unsubstantiated statements and bias - this is an objective investigation. It is essential that you critique your chosen theory and evidence, do not just describe it; evaluate the contribution it makes to our understanding of transforming/transformed consumer behaviour and how marketing
19
 Postgraduate Module Handbook 2022-23

to consumers (as customers or event participants) will evolve as a result in the future.
Not sure what to choose? Maybe this article will help: Rust, Roland T. (2020). The future of Marketing, International Journal of Research in Marketing, 37(1), 15-26.
To help develop your ideas and your ‘future imagination’, refer to the academic articles published in “Futures” in the suggested readings at the end of this assignment briefing. This is a starting point, please source others relevant to your chosen topic.
To see an example of an imaginative future go to Dermody, J., Koenig-Lewis, N., Zhao, A. L., & Hanmer-Lloyd, S. (2021). Critiquing a Utopian Idea of Sustainable Consumption: A Post-Capitalism Perspective. Journal of Macromarketing, 41(4), 626–645. https://doi.org/10.1177/0276146720979148
Further readings will be added to Moodle, as appropriate. Please also refer to the readings attached to each topic, as these may also be relevant for your essay.
Presenting coursework for assessment
Your assignment when submitted should not include your name – we use a system of anonymous marking to reduce the risk of any unconscious bias. For some authentic assessments, there may be an exception to this, so please confirm with your Module Leader.
We suggest the following format for your essay, which mimics the marking criteria listed in the table below, Please discuss with your seminar leader if you wish to depart from this structure:
Part 1: Introduction and Explanation (500-800 words): Introduce and examine your societal challenge, consumer segment and behaviour and country. Explain the issue clearly and its impact, citing supporting evidence and justify why it is worthy of exploration in your essay. Include a profile of your chosen consumer segment.
Part 2: Evaluation and application of theoretical framework (1500-1800 words): Begin by giving an overview of identity theory, then focus on your chosen identity framework/model. Explain it and apply it to you challenge and context in part 1. Evaluate its contribution in explaining the CB transformation that is occurring, using scholarly research and evidence to support your arguments. Use examples throughout, pertinent to your focus. Images and illustrations can be used and add value to written arguments.
20
  Postgraduate Module Handbook 2022-23

Part 3: Conclusions (300-500 words): Develop conclusions based on your content in parts 1 and 2. Do not simply summarise your essay (this is not a conclusion). Your conclusions should be insightful and analytical and lead into your future appraisal. They should also demonstrate your learning from critically reviewing your chosen context and identity theory. Developing a ‘visual map’ to illustrate this can be a useful communication tool; this is entirely up to you. Examples are discussed in the assignment briefings and clinics. Keep your writing style concise and focused. Numbering each conclusion will be helpful for cross referencing with your future appraisal. You could also consider these as a map for part 4.
Part 4: The future (<500 words): This is where you get to be creative! Tell us, based on your analysis in part 1,2 and 3 your core ideas for imagining how consumers and their behaviour will evolve in the future in response to this challenge, and how marketing will need to adapt to continue to engage with them. Include specific examples of your chosen issue/segment/behaviour. You can present your ‘future imagination’ as text and visually (we are not expecting artwork from you). Visualisation is encouraged and can include multiple formats, e.g. drawing, photographs, and digital images. Infographics are useful, using free software that is readily available. Check permissions for using any images that are not your own (and reference them as instructed by the owners).
Make sure your discussion of the future is connected and builds upon what you have stated in the body of your essay and is backed by evidence.
Please note:
Parts 1 and 2 need to be fully and extensively referenced.
Part 3 will contain some pertinent references to support your insight e.g. from futurism, but should not repeat the full range of references in your theory review. Remember conclusions represent your critical thinking built from your prior analysis which you have already referenced.
Part 4 does not require references, albeit you may need to reference some futurism insights if you include them here instead of in your conclusion (either place is fine). This section is showcasing your critical and creative thinking.
The use of subheadings to break up the essay is OK, however, please ensure you don’t have too many as you risk hyper-fragmenting your essay, which may hamper the flow of discussion and subsequent analysis.

title: Service Management
description:
1.	The innovative ‘new’ services is the core/fundamental part to your report, and the beginning/start to guide your further discussion of your marketing strategies/marketing mix. Thus, highlighting the ‘shining point’ (i.e., unique selling point) that differentiate your services from other competitors is very important, which will largely influence the quality of your whole report. 

2.	Be realistic, remember that you also need to propose the launch schedule.

3.	Be consistent, from the motivation of the new services (why you want to invest in your project) to targeting the right segments (you think they will buy your services) to the marketing strategies (how can you realize your project), you should talk about/sell one ‘story’.

4.	With the word limit of 2,000, it is difficult and dangerous to list many points of your (small) practices, especially those could be shared with many other services/ your competitors. In other words, when you talk about the common practices (which you think is very important for your service), you could briefly mention and discuss, or could even summarize it and put it into appendix (show that you learned what was covered in the module). What you should focus and elaborate are those points that you think could show the ‘new’, ‘difference’ and ‘innovative’ of your services (show your creativity and innovation ability). 

5.	As we have discussed the Ps (process, people, and physical evidence, and promotion) which are relevant to services, I recommend you to focus on the contents covered in the module. But if you think some classical Ps (e.g., product, price, place) are very important/special/innovative in your services, you could discuss them, but please justify them. 

6.	Remember when you list any practice, it is better give some support (e.g., theory, statistics as reference) to justify yourself. Avoid listing any implementation without any justification or reference support. 

7.	Remember to propose a ’name’ to your services

title: Integration of AI and automation in Human Resources
description:
2.	Instructions and guidance
           The aim of the proposal
The research proposal requires you to demonstrate your ability to identify, analyse a research problem related to business and management, and to set out a plan for a research project to investigate that problem. The aim of this assessment is to enable you to develop and demonstrate your ability to: (a) diagnose a problem in business and management, (b) arrive at the consequent research questions, (c) determine how to answer these questions by drawing on the academic literature, (d) assess the potential of different research methods and (e) plan a small-scale research project.  
Your report is intended to form the plan for how you might use the literature (by drawing on the ideas and findings of others), design a research project and analyse the findings.  
This report is among the most challenging assignments set during the M.Sc. programmes. You are being asked to anticipate the issues that will confront you in conducting a small research project. Thus, it is quite different from and more difficult than, writing a conventional coursework paper. The best reports are usually those produced by those students who have devoted considerable thought to the assignment before even beginning to write the report.  
Your choice of problem for the project proposal report does not commit you to that topic for your dissertation. You can just complete the report as a free-standing exercise in which you are assessed on your ability to analyse a problem, grasp the arguments and the evidence contained in the literature and devise a suitable research design. You are free to select a different topic for your dissertation if you so wish, although there are obvious advantages in sticking to a topic to which you have already given thought and invested some work (although you must avoid cutting and-pasting parts of the proposal into the dissertation).  

 
        The Research Proposal requirements
        The report must include the following main elements: 
1.	Title. This can include a subtitle and should indicate what the research is essentially about. 
2.	Abstract. The abstract sums up the research problem/questions, research design and methods, and relation to the literature and/or practice. 
3.	Introduction in the form of an analysis of the problem to be addressed. This introductory material should include a clear statement of the problem, the question(s) to be researched, the importance of those questions and an indication of the potential role of business and management theories in answering the questions. The introduction should have clear labelling of the aim and objectives. 
4.	A summary critical review of the relevant literature, both theoretical and applied. This section should indicate what can be learnt from the current literature and will seek to identify some of the strengths and weaknesses of that literature. You are not expected to provide a comprehensive guide to the literature, but you are expected to communicate an understanding of some of the main theoretical ideas and presently available evidence relating to your topic. You must refer to the academic literature and not just to the professional literature (note that the former usually involves seeking an in-depth and critical understanding of problems while the latter is usually restricted to matters of 'how-to-do-it'). 
5.	An outline of the proposed research design and methods. You should outline the research design and the likely methods, taking care to point to the strengths and weaknesses of your proposed research methods. You must outline a research project that can feasibly be done within the constraints of the M.Sc. dissertation process, indicate that you have good reason to believe that the necessary data is available and can be collected, that your choice of method(s) is appropriate and likely to produce reliable and valid results, and that you have considered any ethical questions raised by the research. 
6.	Conclusion. The conclusion summarizes the problem, the purposes of the study, the research question/s, and the methodology. It should also acknowledge any possible limitations of the approach 
(e.g. any problems of generalizability from limited number of cases). 
7.	Documentation: Appendix, references, and general presentation of the work. Using the Harvard approach to referencing and the references are done correctly in alphabetic order. You may include an appendix for any additional material you consider relevant, however the appendix will not be assessed. Diagrams and tables should be numbered, captioned, and presented correctly. 

To pass the assignment, you must include all these key elements. However, you do not have to devote an equal number of words to each of them. In particular, the analysis of the problem is very likely to be shorter than the other elements. 
What you should NOT do (these reflect the failings of past research proposals)
•	Do not write an essay about a general topic.  
•	Do not just describe the application of a particular management technique or method (e.g. TQM, a project management technique), you must analyse the underlying problem and critically evaluate the alternative 'solutions'. 
•	Do not write a literature review that is solely or largely dependent on pop management books or the professional rather than the academic literature. 
•	Do not write a literature review in the form of an annotated bibliography. 
•	Do not write a general essay on research methods. Instead critically evaluate those methods you are likely to use. 
•	Do not include lots of incidental, trivial detail about how you would actually carry out the research.  
What makes for a good research proposal  
There are many ways to write a project proposal report, and we have no particular model answer in mind. The following are some of the points we are looking for: 
•	You must have a problem which you can analyse, define and for which you can devise feasible research questions. 
•	You should explain the main issues in your chosen topic and their wider academic and practical relevance. 
•	When reviewing the literature, you should communicate an awareness of the quality of the evidence on which an author draws and of the methodological issues posed by the way in which that evidence has been gathered. 
•	You should give a sense of how the literature has developed and identify the main themes of schools of thought in the literature. How do later articles and contributions in books build on the earlier results findings, and ideas in the literature? 
•	Most importantly, you should be critical and evaluative.  Do not just describe the literature you survey, explain why the authors have arrived at the conclusions they have. State whether you consider the authors have achieved their aims. Explain any weaknesses you feel there are in specific articles or books and, if possible, how those weaknesses could have been overcome. It is better to evaluate critically fewer references rather than cite many references with little critical appraisal. 
•	You should indicate the wider significance of your study – what are the wider implications of what you have found both for the academic literature (whose approaches/viewpoints/hypotheses do your findings support?) and for practice (e.g. should people in organizations do things differently as a result?). 
•	Observe the usual requirements for a good presentation – be grammatical, use punctuation marks correctly, try to avoid jargon etc. You should use headings and sub-headings to organise your material. 
 
Formal Requirements
The report should be no more than 3000 words in length (excluding the bibliography), with a 10% upper limit and should be organised as indicated above. 
 The report should be double-spaced, well presented and structured. Appendices should only be used when judged to be strictly necessary to understand the project. The work should use the Harvard system of references, and all references should be included in a properly presented bibliography.

title: The impact of big data analytics on understanding customer needs within the retail sector"
description:
Assessment Brief – Dissertation
You need to write an individual research proposal (100%). You are expected to develop a suitable and realistic research proposal, with a view to
undertaking a focused piece of contemporary research with clear and tangible outcomes of interest and relevance to the work context. The
topic that you choose to study for your research is your own choice but should relate to business and management disciplines, and in particular
to your specific Master programme subject. For example, if you're studying the MSc International Business & Marketing Management, your
dissertation should focus on a marketing topic, such as digital marketing, media and advertising, brand management, etc. You will need to
decide on the area of research for your Research Proposal fairly quickly – in just a few weeks.
Ideally, your Research Proposal should be something novel that will have practical value to businesses or other organisations. It should have a
theoretical perspective as well as a practical purpose. One idea is to take a favourite management area (e.g., marketing) and an area of
personal interest (e.g., SMEs in the hospitality sector) and then develop a project into e.g., the marketing of SMEs in the hospitality sector.
Alternatively, look for something topical in the news that has a business perspective. Some students use the project to develop their knowledge
of an area within which they hope to develop a career. The lectures, seminars and your reading will help you to decide on your topic and the
best research approach to use. However, if you are really struggling, we are available to give advice.
Research Proposal Structure
The following information is a general overview of the structure and contents of a Research Proposal and additionally summarises what should
be demonstrated by the proposal and by you as a researcher. This is not a definitive structure, only a guideline that covers all the important
areas in a logical manner. There is flexibility to adjust or change this structure depending on your individual needs. The following elements may
form subheadings for your research proposal document. The numbers in brackets are a guide of how many words are required for each section.
However, they are only a guide and not definitive.
Working title (maximum 12 words)
This should capture the essence of your project, and includes information which relates to the proposed study which you wish to undertake.
Introduction (approximately 300 words)
● What are you exploring and why?
● Put the research into context.
● Why is it important to study this topic (rationale)?
1
● Clearly identify your research question/problem.
● What are the specific aims and objectives of the research?
Literature review (approximately 700 words)
This section should identify and critically review the key literature that has been written on your topic. It should compare and contrast
perspectives that have been gleaned from reading and investigating the subject. While this might come from textbooks, journal articles and
other reports, journal articles will be your main source. The review might also include more practitioner-based studies which are of
significance. Remember, it is important to look for themes in the literature, not just describe one article after another. Make sure you reference
everything clearly and be careful not to plagiarise. Also, make sure you clearly show the importance of the literature you are writing about to
your topic. DO NOT just put slabs of unrelated literature in your literature review. Please show the reader why it is in there. What does it mean
to your project?
Methodology (approximately 900 words)
Provide a clear and justified statement of your proposed research approach to address your research question/aim. You should provide a clear
rationale for your choice of method(s), with a clear link to your research question/aim. You should also include a critical evaluation of the
strengths and limitations of your proposed approach. This section could include: (a) data collection method(s) to be used with justifications, (b)
participants where appropriate (population, sample size, access), (c) ethical considerations and potential limitations and ways to overcome
them, (d) research philosophy which will underpin the dissertation if relevant.
A feasible and detailed Action Plan (approximately 100 words)
Assume you will be implementing your project plan during June-January, provide a realistic, detailed and practical action plan. You should
provide a graphical form, for example, a Gantt chart, including key milestones of your research against specific dates, i.e. research schedule
showing the target completion date for each task or activity (review of literature, data collection, data analysis, write-up, first draft to your
supervisor, etc.). You could also include the resources needed to undertake the proposed research.
2
References (excluded from word count, minimum 20 references)
Create a Reference List of only the sources you have cited in the body of your proposal. Please do not include anything that is not in the body of
your proposal. In-text citations and the reference list should use the Harvard style. Appropriate referencing is important to avoid plagiarism so
please take this seriously. Please read the guidelines and regulations provided later for more specific details.
assignment_type: ["Report Writing","Literature Review","Research Paper","Primary / Secondary Data Analysis"]
filename: Research module handbook.pdf_$_Research example 3.pdf_$_Research example 2.pdf_$_Research example 1.pdf_$_Research assesment.pdf_$_
